{{Use Pakistani English|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox music festival | music_festival_name = All Pakistan Music Conference | image= | location = [[Lahore]], Pakistan<ref name=Tribune/> | years active = 15 September 1959 – present<ref name=Tribune/> | founders = Musicologist [[Hayat Ahmad Khan]] in 1959<ref name=Tribune/> | dates = Annual [[music festival]]<ref name=Tribune/> | genre = [[Qawaali]], [[Hindustani Classical Music|Classical]], [[Pakistani pop|Pop]], [[Pakistani rock|Rock]], [[Hamd]], [[Ghazal]] }}
The '''All Pakistan Music Conference''' (APMC) was founded in 1959 for the promotion of [[Hindustani classical music|classical music]] in Pakistan. Ever since its inception, it has been a constant source of inspiration for thousands of music lovers nationwide. APMC has been holding an annual 6-day-music-festival of live performances by the musicians of Pakistan for more than 50 years now.<ref name=Dawn>[https://www.dawn.com/news/1135708 All Pakistan Music Conference from 13 October 2014], Dawn (newspaper), Published 2 October 2014, Retrieved 2 September 2018</ref>
==History== At the time of the [[Pakistan Movement|independence]] of [[Pakistan]] in 1947, Pakistan was so beset with insurmountable social, economic and political problems that fine arts virtually remained neglected. Upto that point in 1947, history's largest migration of people had totally upset the equilibrium of the population not only physically but also emotionally and psychologically. During such times, the arts could not get attention of the people or the government. [[Pakistani music]] was neglected more than all else. People only heard [[Radio Pakistan]] play some music now and then. The memory of live music concerts lingered in the minds of a few. If lovers of music had nostalgic memories, the musicians were totally frustrated and felt neglected. The height of despair was reflected in the decision of Ustad [[Bade Ghulam Ali Khan]] to leave his birthplace [[Pakistan]] to go back to [[India]]. Soon after, [[Roshan Ara Begum]] announced that she was giving up [[Riyaz]] ([[music practice]]) as no one seemed interested in listening to her music. Her announcement jolted concerned citizens into action. Accepting the challenge, they decided to find ways and means to revive and rejuvenate the seemingly lost but rich and glorious heritage of classical music.
On 15 September 1959, these concerned citizens met at the famous Coffee House of Lahore and launched a voluntary organization under the title of The All Pakistan Music Conference. The main objective of the APMC was to promote music and musicians by organizing concerts, conferences and festivals. It was decided to hold, as soon as possible, a large event on national level to focus attention on our melodic culture. A festival of [[Folk music|folk]], light, semi-classical and classical music was announced for 19 February 1960 to 23 February 1960. Spread over five evening and two morning sessions, the festival was an instant success. Musicians from all over the country had participated. People from all walks of life, from all the big cities, [[Dhaka]], [[Quetta]], [[Karachi]] and [[Peshawar]], and from towns and villages all over Pakistan attended the concerts in large numbers. This music festival has recently been held at the [[Alhamra Arts Council]] in [[Lahore]].<ref name=Dawn/> The programme started daily at eight in the evening and lasted for five to six hours with the last evening closing a couple of hours after sunrise – a glorious day had dawned. The festival was the first major step which gave new lease of life to music in Pakistan. Followed by monthly concerts, it helped promote this noble art. Simultaneously, the festival helped project musicians. Great masters of whom the general public had not even heard and who were hidden even from the discerning eye were brought to the forefront.
==Objectives== The late [[Hayat Ahmad Khan]] (1921 – 6 February 2005) had been the moving spirit behind All Pakistan Music Conference. He was not only one of its founding members but also a long-serving secretary.<ref name=Dawn1>[https://www.dawn.com/news/401663 Hayat Ahmad Khan's services eulogized (founder of All Pakistan Music Conference)], Dawn (newspaper), Published 9 February 2005, Retrieved 2 September 2018</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/334681/tribute-apmc-remembers-hayat-ahmed-khan/ |author=Sher Khan|title=Tribute: APMC (All Pakistan Music Conference) remembers Hayat Ahmad Khan|newspaper=The Express Tribune (newspaper)|date=11 February 2012|accessdate=2 September 2018}}</ref>
To encourage the classical musicians/vocalists living in obscurity after the [[Pakistan Movement|independence]] of [[Pakistan]] in 1947, and particularly influenced by [[Roshan Ara Begum]]'s probable intention to give up her 'Riyaz' due to the lack of interested listeners in Pakistan, Mr. Hayat along with several music connoisseurs laid the foundation of APMC. This project, he hoped, would rejuvenate interest in classical music in Pakistan. Many well-established artists like [[Roshan Ara Begum]], [[Akhtari Bai]], [[Rasoolan Bai]], Ustad [[Bade Ghulam Ali Khan]], Ustad [[Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan|Fateh Ali Khan]], Ustad '''Salamat Ali Khan''' and Ustad [[Ghulam Hassan Shaggan]] have performed at APMC concerts.<ref name=Dawn/>
Over the years, APMC has also brought forth several amateurs in the field of classical music. Notable names include Fahim Mazhar, Abdur Rauf, Sara Zaman and several others. APMC attracts music luminaries and aspiring artists alike to keep the classical music alive in the country. Not only that, both vocalists and [[instrumentalists]] from [[Afghanistan]], [[Turkey]], [[India]], [[Japan]], the [[United States]] and [[Germany]], have benefited from the regular musical sittings held at APMC over the past 59 years as of 2017.<ref name=Tribune>{{cite web|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1547329/1-entertainment-59th-music-festival-start-nov-21/ |publisher=Associated Press of Pakistan (APP) news agency|title=Entertainment: 59th Music Festival to start from Nov 21|newspaper=The Express Tribune (newspaper)|date=2 November 2017|accessdate=2 September 2018}}</ref>
The APMC programmes, held on a monthly basis greatly enrich the cultural ethos of Lahore. Besides these monthly mehfils, APMC also hosts a yearly six-day festival in which musicians/vocalists from all over Pakistan perform till the wee hours of morning.<ref name=Dawn/>
Few would know that APMC has also been instrumental in promoting classical dance in Pakistan. Classical dance performances of Naheed Siddiqui, [[Gopi Krishna (dancer)|Gopi Krishna]] and [[Sheema Kermani]] hosted by the organization stand as evidence.
==Famous performing musicians at APMC== * Akmal Qadri – ([[Bansuri]] or flute player) * [[Haider Rahman]] ([[Bansuri]] or flute player)) * Mian Qadir Bukhsh Pakhawaji (founder of [[Punjab gharana]] of [[tabla]] players) * Khalifa Akhtar Hussain * Dildar Ali * Amir Chouhan from [[Peshawar]] * Ustad [[Bade Ghulam Ali Khan]]<ref name=Dawn/> * Nazakat Ali Khan, ([[Sham Chaurasia gharana]]) * Salamat Ali Khan, ([[Sham Chaurasia gharana]])<ref name=Dawn/> * [[Amanat Ali Khan]] ([[Patiala gharana]]) * [[Bade Fateh Ali Khan]] ([[Patiala gharana]])<ref name=Dawn/> * [[Barkat Ali Khan]] ([[Patiala gharana]]) * [[Sharif Khan Poonchwaley]] ([[sitar]] [[Player (band)|player]]) * Sardar Khan * Nathu Khan ([[sarangi]] player) * Allah Ditta Pari Paikar * [[Mian Shaukat Hussain]] (Tabla Player) * Nazim Ali Khan * Munir Sarhadi * Zahida Parveen * Sadiq Ali Mando * Khamisu Khan ([[Alghoza]] player) * Sain Akhter Hussain ([[Folk singer]]) * Latafat Hussain Khan * Niaz Hussain Shami * [[Ghulam Hassan Shaggan]] (Classical vocalist of [[Gwalior gharana]])<ref name=Dawn/> * [[Naseem Begum]] (film playback singer and television performer) * Nabi Bakhsh ([[tabla]] [[Player (band)|player]]) * Umeed Ali Khan * Zahoori Khan * Adbur Rashid Beenkaar * [[Tufail Niazi]] (folk singer) * Talib Hussain * Lal Mohammad of [[Lal Mohammad Iqbal]] group (film music composers) * [[Roshan Ara Begum]] (Classical music singer of [[Kirana gharana]])<ref name=Dawn/> * [[Mohammad Aizaz Sohail]] (Karnatak and Khayal Singer) * Sannan Mahboob ([[Rubab (instrument)|Rubab]] player)
==See also== * [[Music of Pakistan]] * [[Qawaali]] * [[Ghazal]] * [[Danka Culture Guide|Danka – Pakistan's Cultural Events Guide]]

{{Infobox organization | name = Alliance Française de Lagos | logo = | type = French cultural and language center | founded_date = 1959 | founder = | location =239, Herbert Macaulay Street, Alagomeji, Yaba, [[Lagos]], [[Lagos State]], Nigeria | origins = | key_people = | area_served = [[Lagos State]] | product = French [[Culture of France|cultural]] and [[French language|language]] education | focus = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | staff = | dissolved = | website = | footnotes = }}
The '''Alliance Francaise of Lagos''' ([[French language|French]]: l'Alliance Française de lagos) is a Nigerian [[non-profit]] institution in [[Lagos]] whose statutes have been approved by the ''[[Alliance Française|Alliance Française of Paris]]''. The Institute is involved with the training and education of Nigerians, most especially Lagosians in the [[French language]] and [[Culture of France|culture]].
==History== The Institute was established in 1959.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ajntAAAAMAAJ&q=alliance+francaise+lagos+established+year+history&dq=alliance+francaise+lagos+established+year+history|title=The Mobilizer|volume=4|number=6|author=((Ministry of Home Affairs, Information, and Culture))|publisher=Borno State Orientation Movement (Indiana University)|year=1991}}</ref><ref name=Afrique>{{cite web|url=http://www.afriqueinvisu.org/alliance-francaise-de-lagos,322.html|website=Afrique in Visu |language=French|title=Alliance Française de Lagos, Nigeria|accessdate=July 29, 2015}}</ref> About 4,000 students register annually at the Institute for their programmes. It is the headquarters of the General Delegation of the French Alliance of Paris in Nigeria. There are ten sister locations in other parts of Nigeria including Enugu, Ibadan, Ilorin, Jos, Kano, Kaduna, Lagos, Maiduguri, Owerri and Port Harcourt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.institutfrancais-nigeria.com/the-french-cultural-network-in-nigeria/|website=Institute francaise|title=The French cultural network in Nigeria|accessdate=July 29, 2015}}</ref> The Lagos Institute is the largest alliance in Africa. As one of the worldwide networks of [[Alliance française|Alliances]], it works closely with the Alliance Française Foundation in [[Paris]] and the Nigerian government.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=omL5460steUC&pg=PA144&dq=Alliance+Francaise+French+Center+Lagos+Nigeria#v=onepage&q=Alliance%20Francaise%20French%20Center%20Lagos%20Nigeria&f=false|title=Alliance Française (French Cultural Center) |publisher=Bradt Travel Guides, 2012|isbn=9781841623979|author=Lizzie Williams|author2=Mark Shenley|year=2012 }}</ref> As the operator leading to the promotion of French language and culture, it is supported by the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The French Alliance is also bound by agreement to the [[Lagos State Ministry of Education|Ministry of Education of Lagos State]] for a period of 10 years renewable under a continuing education program for French teachers of the state.
==Cultural Events== Social and cultural events organised by the institute includes electronic music workshops,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pulse.ng/events/electronic-soundscapes-press-conference-held-ahead-of-the-main-event-id3851017.html|title=Press conference held ahead of the main event|author=Namand Bannah|publisher=The Pulse}}</ref> ''The World Music Day'' event, the annual ''Life in my city'' art exhibition,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bizwatchnigeria.ng/alliance-francaise-de-lagos-monthly-art-exhibition-story-mind-bona-ezeudu/|publisher=Bizwatch|title=ALLIANCE FRANÇAISE DE LAGOS MONTHLY ART EXHIBITION: THE STORY OF MY MIND|author1=Bona Ezeudu|date=April 28, 2014|author2=Afolakemi O.|accessdate=July 30, 2015}}</ref> and the ''Dance meet Danse'' festival, to name a few.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/life-in-my-city-comes-to-lagos/155996/|title=Life in My City Comes to Lagos|publisher=Thisdaylive|date=August 11, 2013|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Alliance Française]]
==References== {{reflist}}

[[Image:TeenTitansTogether.png|thumb|right|The main characters of ''[[Teen Titans (TV series)|Teen Titans]]'' (2003–2006).]]
'''Anime-influenced animation''', or '''American anime''',<ref>{{cite web|year=1997 |author=Kime, Chad |url=http://www.ex.org/3.3/14-column_riap.html |title=American Anime: Blend or Bastardization? |work=EX 3.3 |publisher=EX.org |accessdate=2006-07-29 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060901114713/http://www.ex.org/3.3/14-column_riap.html |archivedate=1 September 2006 |deadurl=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | author = Khan, Ridwan | url = http://www.animefringe.com/magazine/2003/07/editorial/02/ | title = American Anime - Is it Possible? | publisher = Animefringe.com |date=July 2003 | accessdate = 2006-07-29 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060615054241/http://www.animefringe.com/magazine/2003/07/editorial/02/| archivedate= 15 June 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> refers to non-Japanese works of [[animation]] that are similar to or inspired by [[anime]].
Although outside Japan, ''anime'' is specifically used to mean animation from Japan or as a Japanese-disseminated animation [[Style (aesthetics)|style]] often characterized by colorful graphics, vibrant characters and fantastical themes,<ref name="webster">{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/anime|title=Anime|year=2011|publisher=Merriam-Webster|accessdate=March 9, 2012}}</ref><ref name=anna /> there is a debate over whether the culturally abstract approach to the word's meaning may open up the possibility of anime produced in countries other than Japan.<ref name="rwby">{{cite web|last=Rush|first=Amanda|title=FEATURE: Inside Rooster Teeth's "RWBY"|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2013/07/12/feature-inside-rooster-teeths-rwby|publisher=Crunchyroll|accessdate=July 18, 2013|date=July 12, 2013}}</ref><ref name=escapist>{{cite web|last=O'Brien|first=Chris|title=Can Americans Make Anime?|url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/articles/view/features/9829-Can-Americans-Make-Anime|work=The Escapist|publisher=The Escapist|accessdate=July 17, 2013|date=July 30, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Torkaizer">{{cite web|last=Fakhruddin|first=Mufaddal|title='Torkaizer', Middle East's First Anime Show|url=http://me.ign.com/en/news/9594/-torkaizer-middle-east-s-first-anime-show|publisher=IGN|accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref> While some Westerners strictly view anime as a Japanese animation product,<ref name=anna>{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/encyclopedia/lexicon.php?id=45 |title=Anime News Network Lexicon - Anime |accessdate=April 22, 2013}}</ref> some scholars suggest defining anime as specifically or quintessentially Japanese may be related to a new form of [[orientalism]].{{sfn|Ruh|2014|pages=134–135}}
==Background== Generally, the term [[anime]] refers to a style of animation originating from Japan. As Japanese anime became increasingly popular, Western animation studios began implementing some visual stylizations typical in anime—such as exaggerated facial expressions and "[[super deformed]]" versions of characters. In particular, ''[[Batman Beyond]]''<ref name="ANN2"/> displayed some characteristics of anime. Particularly for ''Batman Beyond'', some of its production processes were outsourced to Japan.<ref name="ANN2">{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/answerman/2003-10-17|title=Ms. Answerman: The Internet Question Massacre|date=2003-10-17|accessdate=2007-08-09|work=Rebecca Bundy, ANN}}</ref>
===United States=== [[File:Thebats.jpg|thumb|right|''[[The Batman]]'' (2004–2008) characters.]]
One of the first noted attempts from American companies on making anime is in ''[[The King Kong Show]]'' in late 60s and early 70s. This animation was the result of a collaboration between [[Toei Animation]] from Japan and ''Videocraft'' from America. The result was an animation with an Anime-like visual style and a Japanese Kaiju theme, that incorporated the cartoonish style of the Hanna-Barbera era in American TV animation. Another early example of this might be ''[[Johnny Cypher in Dimension Zero]]''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Clements|first=Jonathan|authorlink=Jonathan Clements|author2=McCarthy, Helen |authorlink2=Helen McCarthy |title=''[[The Anime Encyclopedia]]''|publisher=[[Stone Bridge Press]]|edition=2nd expanded|location=[[Berkeley, California]]|year=2006|page=313340|isbn=1-84576-500-1}}</ref>
Toei Animation continued this kind of collaborations in the ''[[The Transformers (TV series)|Transformers]]'' TV series, which aired in the 80s. While this animation was actually animated by Toei Animation, the series was produced by and for Americans. Transformers truly showed many influences and elements of anime including story, themes and its style that completely resembled [[Mecha]] anime. Another example of this is ''[[Voltron]]''; an American mecha series that reuses the animation from previously released Toei Japanese anime, creating a new story written by American writers.
This trend continued throughout the 80s with animations like ''[[Dungeons & Dragons (TV series)|Dungeons and Dragons]]'', again co-produced by Toei Animation. Furthermore, through the 90s, many American shows started to be outsourced to Japanese animators, most notably [[TMS Entertainment]], which animated popular television productions such as ''[[DuckTales]]'', ''[[Animaniacs]]'' and ''[[Spider-Man (1994 TV series)|Spider-Man]]'', most of which visually or thematically were not resembling Japanese anime. <ref>{{IMDb title|0085011|Dungeons & Dragons}}</ref>
During the 90s, some American animations started showing strong influence from anime without having any Japanese artists directly involved in the project. An example of this can be seen in [[Cartoon Network]] shows like ''[[The Powerpuff Girls]]'' and ''[[Dexter's Laboratory]]'' or the [[Disney Channel]] show, ''[[Kim Possible]]''.
Some other notable example of this anime-influenced shows are ''[[Batman the Animated Series]]'' which was actually partially outsourced to Japanese artists, ''[[Gargoyles (TV series)|Gargoyles]]'', and more recently ''[[Teen Titans (TV series)|Teen Titans]]'' and ''[[The Batman (TV series)|The Batman]]''.
The advent of Japanese anime stylizations appearing in Western animation questioned the established meaning of "anime".<ref name="whatisanime">{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/editorial/2002-07-26|title=What is anime?|date=2002-07-26|work=ANN|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070820052800/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/editorial/2002-07-26|archivedate=20 August 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no|accessdate=2007-08-18}}</ref> The production on ''[[The Animatrix]]'' began when the [[Wachowskis]] visited some of the creators of the anime films that had been strong influences on their work, and decided to collaborate with them.<ref>"What is Animatrix?" feature on ''[[The Matrix Revisited]]'' DVD.</ref>
''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'', and its sequel series ''[[The Legend of Korra]]'' are other examples of Western anime so heavily influenced by Japanese anime that they started discussions among fans and viewers about what is an Anime and should a non-Japanese animation be called an Anime.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://news.awn.com/index.php?ltype=top&newsitem_no=13156 | title = Avatar: The Last Airbender Article | accessdate = 2006-12-16 |date=2005-02-18 | publisher = Animation World Magazine| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061217011106/http://news.awn.com/index.php?ltype=top&newsitem_no=13156| archivedate= 17 December 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> ''Avatar'' creators [[Bryan Konietzko]] and [[Michael Dante DiMartino]] confirmed a particular Japanese anime influence in a magazine interview; that of "[[Hayao Miyazaki]], especially ''[[Spirited Away]]'' and ''[[Princess Mononoke]]''"<ref name = "musogato_elements">{{cite web|url=http://www.musogato.com/avatar/magazine/avatarmag1_scan08.jpg|title="In Their Elements." (September 2006) ''Nick Mag Presents'', p. 6}}</ref> as well as ''[[My Neighbor Totoro]]''.<ref>{{Cite video | people = Bryan Konietzko and Michael Dante DiMartino | title = Book 1: Water, Box Set | medium = DVD |date=2006-09-19}}</ref> Other studios from which inspiration was drawn include [[Studio 4°C]], [[Production I.G]], [[Polygon Pictures]] and [[Studio Ghibli]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musogato.com/avatar/magazine/anime_insider-dec06.jpg|title=Anime Insider: December 2006|accessdate=2007-03-20}}</ref>
The same strong resemblance can be seen in ''[[Voltron: Legendary Defender]]'', a [[reboot (fiction)|reboot]] of ''[[Voltron]]'' franchise, this time completely produced by American artists. [[Lauren Montgomery]] and [[Joaquim Dos Santos]], both known for their work on the ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'' and its sequel ''[[The Legend of Korra]]'', served as showrunners while fellow crew member Tim Hedrick served as head writer.
These anime-influenced animations have become defined as "anime", in an attempt to classify all Japanese-anime styled works of non-Japanese origin.<ref name="whatisanime"/> The web-based series ''[[RWBY]]'' is produced using an anime art style and has been declared to be anime.<ref name=rwby /><ref>{{cite web|last=Lazar|first=Shira|title=Roosterteeth Adds Anime RWBY To YouTube Slate (WATCH)|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/shira-lazar/roosterteeth-adds-anime-r_b_3720316.html|publisher=Huffingtonpost|accessdate=August 15, 2013|date=August 7, 2013}}</ref> In addition, the series was released in Japan, under the label of "anime" per the Japanese definition of the term and referenced as an "American-made anime".<ref>{{cite web|title=海外3DCGアニメ『RWBY』吹き替え版BD・DVD販売決定！ コミケで発表|url=http://kai-you.net/article/7931|website=KAI-YOU|accessdate=2014-08-19|date=2014-08-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Castillo|first1=Michelle|title=American-Made Anime From Rooster Teeth Gets Licensed In Japan|url=http://www.adweek.com/news/technology/american-made-anime-rooster-teeth-gets-licensed-japan-159528|website=AdWeek|publisher=AdWeek|accessdate=2014-08-20|date=2014-08-15}}</ref> Netflix declared the company's intention to produce anime.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Schley|first1=Matt|title=Netflix May Produce Anime|url=http://www.otakuusamagazine.com/LatestNews/News1/Netflix-May-Produce-Anime-7035.aspx|website=OtakuUSA|publisher=OtakuUSA|accessdate=2015-11-17}}</ref> In doing so, the company is offering a more accessible channel for distribution to Western markets.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Barder|first1=Ollie|title=Netflix Is Interested In Producing Its Own Anime|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/olliebarder/2015/11/04/netflix-is-interested-in-producing-its-own-anime/|website=Forbes|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=2015-11-17}}</ref>
Defining anime as style has been contentious amongst fans, with John Oppliger stating, "The insistence on referring to original American art as "anime" or "manga" robs the work of its cultural identity."<ref name=anna /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.animenation.net/blog/2006/05/15/ask-john-how-should-the-word-anime-be-defined/ |title=How should the word ''Anime'' be defined? |date=May 15, 2006 |accessdate=September 26, 2008 |work=AnimeNation}}</ref> On the other hand, animations like ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'', its ''[[The Legend of Korra|sequel]]'' and ''[[Voltron: Legendary Defender]]'' have opened up more debates on whether these works should be called Anime and whether the culturally abstract approach to the word's meaning may open up the possibility of anime produced in countries other than Japan.<ref name="rwby">{{cite web|last=Rush|first=Amanda|title=FEATURE: Inside Rooster Teeth's "RWBY"|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2013/07/12/feature-inside-rooster-teeths-rwby|publisher=Crunchyroll|accessdate=July 18, 2013|date=July 12, 2013}}</ref><ref name=escapist>{{cite web|last=O'Brien|first=Chris|title=Can Americans Make Anime?|url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/articles/view/features/9829-Can-Americans-Make-Anime|work=The Escapist|publisher=The Escapist|accessdate=July 17, 2013|date=July 30, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Torkaizer">{{cite web|last=Fakhruddin|first=Mufaddal|title='Torkaizer', Middle East's First Anime Show|url=http://me.ign.com/en/news/9594/-torkaizer-middle-east-s-first-anime-show|publisher=IGN|accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref> While some Westerners strictly view anime as a Japanese animation product,<ref name=anna>{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/encyclopedia/lexicon.php?id=45 |title=Anime News Network Lexicon - Anime |accessdate=April 22, 2013}}</ref> some scholars suggest defining anime as specifically or quintessentially Japanese may be related to a new form of [[orientalism]]{{sfn|Ruh|2014|pages=134–135}} with some fans and critics arguing that the term should be defined as a "style" rather than as a national product, which leaves open the possibility of anime being produced in other countries.<ref name="webster"/><ref name=escapist />
Japanese anime has also had an influence on [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Disney]], [[Pixar]] and [[DreamWorks Animation|DreamWorks]] productions. [[Glen Keane]], the animator for successful Disney films such as ''[[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)|The Little Mermaid]]'', ''[[Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)|Beauty and the Beast]]'', ''[[Aladdin (1992 Disney film)|Aladdin]]'' and ''[[Tangled]]'', has credited [[Hayao Miyazaki]] as a "huge influence" on ''[[The Rescuers Down Under]]''.<ref>Michael J. Lee (October 24, 2010), [http://movies.radiofree.com/interviews/tangled_glen_keane.shtml AN EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW WITH GLEN KEANE], RadioFree.com</ref> [[Pete Docter]], director of the popular films ''[[Up (2009 film)|Up]]'' and ''[[Monsters, Inc.]]'' as well as a co-creator of other Pixar works, has also described anime, specifically Miyazaki, as an influence on his work.<ref name=pbs>[http://www.kpbs.org/news/2009/may/29/interview-director-peter-docter/ Interview with Up Director Peter Docter]. By Beth Accomando. [[KPBS (TV)|KPBS]]. Published May 29, 2009.</ref> [[Chris Sanders (director)|Chris Sanders]] and [[Dean DeBlois]] described Miyazaki's flight and pacifist themes as an influence for creating ''[[How to Train Your Dragon (film)|How to Train Your Dragon]]''.
''[[Stitch!]]'' is the [[anime]] [[spin-off (media)|spin-off]] of [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney's]] [[Lilo & Stitch (franchise)|''Lilo & Stitch'' franchise]] and the successor to ''[[Lilo & Stitch: The Series]]''. It debuted in [[Japan]] in October 2008. The show features a Japanese girl named Yuna in place of Lilo, and is set on a fictional island in the [[Ryukyu Islands|Ryukyus]] off the shore of [[Okinawa]] instead of [[Hawaii]].
===Other regions=== [[File:W.I.T.C.H. (TV series).png|thumb|right|The main characters of the ''[[W.I.T.C.H. (TV series)|W.I.T.C.H.]]'' animated series (2004–2006).]]
In the 1980s, there were Japanese-European productions such as ''[[Ulysses 31]]'', ''[[The Mysterious Cities of Gold]]'', ''[[Dogtanian and the Three Muskehounds]]'' and ''[[Sherlock Hound]]''.
The Italian animated series ''[[Winx Club]]'', one of the most popular and successful shows from Europe, uses a [[magical girl]] concept for the main characters, including transformations for each character.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bsckids.com/2016/02/winx-club-receive-live-action-film/|title=Winx Club to Receive Live-Action Film|first=Ella|last=Anders|date=February 13, 2016|work=BSC Kids|accessdate=June 13, 2016}}</ref>
The French-American [[international co-production]] ''[[W.I.T.C.H. (TV series)|W.I.T.C.H.]]'', another magical girl series,<ref>{{cite speech|last=Bellerby|first=Grace|author-link=|title=The History of Magical Girl Anime: Sparkles Without Cullens|event=Amecon 2012|date=August 15, 2012|location=[[Keele University]]|publisher=SlideShare|url=https://www.slideshare.net/gracebellerby/the-hstory-of-magical-girl-anime-sparkles-without-cullens|accessdate=October 18, 2017}}</ref> has been noted as having an anime-influenced visual style.<ref name=nytimes>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/06/arts/television/for-young-viewers-growing-up-galactic.html|title=FOR YOUNG VIEWERS; Growing Up Galactic|first=Jacqueline|last=Cutler|date=6 February 2005|publisher=|accessdate=25 March 2018|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> First season director Marc Gordon-Bates cited anime such as ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion]]'' as design inspiration.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.agni-animation.com/fullerton/halloffame/Marc_Gordon-Bates.html|title=Animators' Hall of Fame|website=www.agni-animation.com|accessdate=October 29, 2018}}</ref> The animated series is based on Italian [[W.I.T.C.H.|comics of the same name]] themselves drawn in line with manga conventions, as opposed to the more rounded style traditionally used by publisher and co-producer [[Disney]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.tefen.com/insights/services/SandM/disneys_journey_to_the_teen_heart|title=Disney's journey to the teen heart|website=en.tefen.com|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
In 2007, the Canadian anime-style animated short ''[[Flutter (animated short)|Flutter]]'' became the first work from a non-Asian nation to win the [[Tokyo Anime Award#Open Entries Grand Prize|Open Entries Grand Prize at the Tokyo Anime Awards]].<ref name="Leader">{{cite news|title=Shia wins top prize|url=http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/arts_life/story.html?id=48d81cd5-fc45-400a-9a2a-2cc63deaf0a3|accessdate=15 January 2011|newspaper=[[Regina Leader-Post]]|date=24 March 2007}}</ref> Another example of anime-influenced animation can be seen in [[Wakfu: The Animated Series]], a [[flash animation]] series based on [[Wakfu|a video game of the same title]].
The producers of the French anime ''[[Code Lyoko]]'', one of the most successful works of European anime, explicitly stated in their introductory document that they were: "Influenced by the poetry and the visual impact of Japanese animation, the series proposes a graphic universe that's particularly original and strong."<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.codelyoko.net/FRA/Garage_Kids/Garage_Kids.pdf |title=Promotional document for ''Garage Kids'' }} {{small|(798 KB)}} Page 2, paragraph 2</ref>
''[[Ōban Star-Racers]]'' is known as one of the European animations that strongly resemble anime. While the majority of the creative directors and writers were French, the production team moved to Tokyo to collaborate with a Japanese production team.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ugo.com/ugo/html/article/?id=17924 |title=Aaron McGruder - The Boondocks Interview |accessdate=October 14, 2007 |work=Troy Rogers |publisher=UnderGroundOnline|quote="We looked at Samurai Champloo and Cowboy Bebop to make this work for black comedy and it would be a remarkable thing."|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071030033247/http://www.ugo.com/ugo/html/article/?id=17924|archivedate=October 30, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.g4tv.com/screensavers/features/49962/Ten_Minutes_with_Megas_XLR.html |title=Ten Minutes with "Megas XLR" |date=October 13, 2004}}</ref><ref name="company">{{cite web |url=http://www.savtheworld.com/eng/company.php |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070813141936/http://www.savtheworld.com/eng/company.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-08-13 |title=STW company background summary }}</ref>
Animation such as ''Oban Star-Racers'' and ''Code Lyoko'', like ''Avatar: The Last Airbender'', are examples over which some critics and fans debate about the term [[anime]] and whether it is defined as a "style" rather than as a national product, which leaves open the possibility of anime being produced in other countries.<ref name="webster"/><ref name=escapist />
A [[United Arab Emirates|U.A.E.]]-[[Philippines|Filipino]] produced TV series called ''Torkaizer'' is dubbed as the "Middle East's First Anime Show", and is currently in production,<ref name=Torkaizer /> which is currently looking for funding.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Green|first1=Scott|title=VIDEO: An Updated Look at "Middle East's First Anime"|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2013/12/26/video-an-updated-look-at-middle-easts-first-anime|website=Crunchyroll|publisher=Crunchyroll|accessdate=2014-08-20|date=2013-12-26}}</ref>
In Brazil since the 2000s there have already been countless independent projects for animated series inspired by anime. Projects to adapt popular manga-styled comics like ''[[Holy Avenger]]'' and ''[[Monica Teen]]'' have already occurred, but were canceled in the course of time. In May 2016, [[Nickelodeon (Brazil)|Nickelodeon]] opened the series ''Os Under-Undergrounds''.<ref>[http://recreio.uol.com.br/noticias/noticias/entrevista-especial---os-under-undergrounds.phtml Entrevista especial - Os Under-Undergrounds!]</ref>
