{{Short description|Willamette Meteorite is an iron-nickel meteorite from the state of Oregon. Is the largest found in North America. Is in New York}}
{{Infobox meteorite | Name= Willamette | Image= Willamette Meteorite AMNH.jpg | Image_caption= Willamette Meteorite at the American Museum of Natural History | Type= [[Iron meteorite|Iron]] | Class= | Group= IIIAn | Structural_classification= Medium [[Octahedrite]] | Composition= 7.62% [[Nickel|Ni]], 18.6ppm [[Gallium|Ga]], 37.3ppm [[Germanium|Ge]], 4.7ppm [[Iridium|Ir]] | Shock= | Weathering= | Country= [[United States]] | Region= [[Oregon]] | Lat_Long= {{coord|45|22|N|122|35|W|display=inline,title}}<ref>[http://www.mindat.org/loc-31274.html Willamette meteorite, West Linn, Clackamas Co., Oregon, USA]. Retrieved on October 30, 2008.</ref> | Observed_fall= No | Fall_date= | Found_date= 1902 | Found_by= Ellis Hughes | TKW= {{convert|14150|kg|ST}}<ref name=AMJ /> | Image2= | Image2_caption= }} The '''Willamette Meteorite''', officially named '''Willamette''',<ref name=database>[http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meteor/metbull.php?code=24269 Meteoritical Bulletin Database: Willamette.] The Meteoritical Society. Retrieved on August 16, 2008.</ref> is an [[Iron meteorite|iron-nickel meteorite]] found in the U.S. state of [[Oregon]]. It is the largest [[meteorite]] found in [[North America]] and the sixth largest in the world.<ref>O. Richard Norton. ''Rocks from Space''. USA, Mountain Press, 1994.</ref><ref name=AMNH>{{cite web |url= http://www.amnh.org/rose/meteorite.html |title= Cullman Hall of the Universe: The Willamette Meteorite |publisher= [[American Museum of Natural History]] |access-date= 2007-11-02 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071221082443/http://www.amnh.org/rose/meteorite.html |archivedate= 2007-12-21 |df=}}</ref> There was no [[impact crater]] at the discovery site; researchers believe the meteorite landed in what is now [[Canada]] or Montana, and was transported as a [[glacial erratic]] to the [[Willamette Valley]] during the [[Missoula Floods]] at the end of the last Ice Age (~13,000 years ago).<ref name=Pugh>{{cite journal |last1=Pugh |first1=R. N. |author2 =Allen J.E. |date=1986 |title= Origin of the Willamette Meteorite |journal= Abstracts and Program for the 49th Annual Meeting of the Meteoritical Society |pages=208 |bibcode=1986LPICo.600E.208P |volume=600}}</ref> It was long held sacred by indigenous peoples of the Willamette Valley, including the federally recognized [[Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde Community of Oregon]] (CTGRC). The indigenous peoples referred to this stone with the name ''Tomanowos'' (a Chinook word meaning "spiritual power").<ref>{{cite news |last1=Alaimo |first1=Michelle |title=Tribal members visit Tomanowos |url=http://www.grandronde.org/news/smoke-signals/2016/06/30/tribal-members-visit-tomanowos/ |accessdate=8 July 2018 |work=Smoke Signals |publisher=The Confederated Tribes of Grand Ronde |date=30 June 2016 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Willamette Meteorite Agreement |url=https://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/permanent-exhibitions/rose-center-for-earth-and-space/dorothy-and-lewis-b.-cullman-hall-of-the-universe/willamette-meteorite-agreement/ |website=American Museum of Natural History |accessdate=8 July 2018}}</ref>
The meteorite is on display at the [[American Museum of Natural History]] in [[New York City]], which acquired it in 1906.<ref name=AMNH /> Having been seen by an estimated 40 million people over the years, and given its striking appearance, it is among the most famous meteorites known.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.chron.com/news/gallery/The-Willamette-Meteorite-27790.php <!-- old URL: http://www.chron.com/news/photogallery/The_Willamette_Meteorite.html --> |date=October 26, 2007 |title=The Willamette Meteorite |work=Houston Chronicle}}</ref><ref name="nyt">{{Cite news |first=Benjamin |last=Weiser |title=Museum Sues to Keep Meteorite Sought by Indian Group |work=The New York Times |date=February 29, 2000 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/29/nyregion/museum-sues-to-keep-meteorite-sought-by-indian-group.html}}</ref><ref>[http://science.discovery.com/top-ten/2009/meteors/meteors-01.html Science Channel's "Top Ten Meteorites"]. Retrieved on November 29th, 2010.</ref> In 2005, the CTGRC sued to have the meteorite returned to their control but they were unsuccessful.<ref name="nyt" />
==Physical characteristics and formation== [[File:Willamette-meteorite-7637.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Close-up of the meteorite]] The Willamette Meteorite weighs about {{convert|32000|lb|kg}}. It is classified as a [[meteorite classification|type III iron meteorite]], being composed of over 91% [[iron]] and 7.62% [[nickel]], with traces of [[cobalt]] and [[phosphorus]]. The approximate dimensions of the meteorite are {{convert|10|feet|m|0}} tall by {{convert|6.5|feet|m|0}} wide by {{convert|4.25|feet|m|1}} deep. Most iron meteorites like Willamette have originated from the differentiated core of planetesimals or [[asteroid]]s that collided with another object. Willamette has a recrystallized structure with only traces of a medium [[Widmanstätten pattern]]; it is the result of a significant impact-heating event on the parent body.<ref name=AMNH /><ref>^ Vagn F. Buchwald: Handbook of Iron Meteorites, University of California Press 1975.</ref> The Willamette Meteorite contains higher concentrations of various metals that are quite rare in Earth's crust. For example, [[Iridium]], one of the least abundant elements in Earth's crust, is found in the Willamette Meteorite at a concentration of 4.7 [[Parts-per notation|ppm]]<!-- vs. having an average mass fraction of 0.001 ppm in crustal rock -->, thousands of times more than its crustal abundance<!-- this image (https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/09/Elemental_abundances.svg) is used in a number of articles to show relative abundance of elements in Earth's crust; probably not appropriate for this article on the WM, but useful to show rarity of various elements. -->.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The chemical classification of iron meteorites—VII. A reinvestigation of irons with Ge concentrations between 25 and 80 ppm|author=Scott, E. R. D.|author2=Wasson, J. T.|author3=Buchwald, V. F. | journal=Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta | date=1973 | volume=37 | pages=1957–1983 | doi=10.1016/0016-7037(73)90151-8 | bibcode = 1973GeCoA..37.1957S|issue=8}}</ref> {{clear|left}}
==Emplacement and erosion== [[Image:Wpdms nasa topo missoula floods.jpg|thumbnail|right|[[Glacial Lake Columbia]] (west) and [[Lake Missoula|Glacial Lake Missoula]] (east, in blue) were south of Cordilleran Ice Sheet. The areas inundated in the Columbia and [[Missoula Floods]] are shown in red. The meteorite was rafted by the floods embedded inside an ice block.]] The lack of an [[impact crater]] at the discovery site was only explained after the 1920s, with the new understanding about the [[Missoula Floods]], one of the largest floods documented, caused by the collapse of an ice barrier during the last deglaciation. The meteorite presumably landed on an ice cap in what is now [[Montana]] or western [[Canada]], and was dragged by the glacier ice to the vicinity of an ice barrier that formed across the [[Clark Fork River]]. This barrier had ponded a huge amount of water at the [[Lake Missoula]] right at the time when the meteorite reached the area and the ice barrier became unstable and breached. The resulting flood involved up to 10 million cubic meters per second of water discharge, with large blocks of ice rafting down the [[Columbia River]] and the [[Willamette Valley]] at the end of the last Ice Age (~13,000 years ago).<ref name=Pugh /> Some of these ice rafts included boulders (known as ''[[glacial erratic]]s'' by geologists) like the Willamette meteorite, which eventually sank in the flood waters and settled where they were found by humans.
The deep crevasses of the meteorite resulted from both its high-speed atmospheric entry and its subsequent weathering. Exposed to the elements for thousands of years, rainwater interacted with the mineral [[troilite]], resulting in a form of [[sulfuric acid]] which slowly dissolved portions of the meteorite. This resulted in the gradual development of the hollows that are visible today.
==Modern history== The Willamette Meteorite was originally found in the Willamette Valley of Oregon near the modern city of [[West Linn, Oregon|West Linn]]. Although already known and sacred to Native Americans, it came to prominence due to the actions of settler Ellis Hughes in 1902. At that time the land was owned by the [[Oregon Iron Company|Oregon Iron and Steel Company]]. Hughes recognized the meteorite's significance, and in an attempt to claim ownership, secretly moved it to his own land. This involved 90 days of hard work to cover the 3/4 mile (1200 m) distance. The move was discovered, and after a lawsuit, the Oregon Supreme Court held that Oregon Iron and Steel Company was the legal owner. [https://books.google.com/books?pg=PA572&dq=&cd=1&id=2QwLAAAAYAAJ#v=PA572&q Oregon Iron Co. v. Hughes, 47 Or 313, 82 P 572 (1905)].<ref>Preston, Douglas. [http://www.usgennet.org/alhnorus/ahorclak/MeteorTreasures.html Strange Journey: Further Travels of The Willamette Meteorite.] Meteor Treasures. Retrieved on October 31, 2007.</ref>
[[Image:willamette meteorite.jpg|left|frame|Willamette Meteorite in the early 20th century]] In 1905, the meteorite was purchased by [[William E. Dodge]] for $26,000 (around $680,000 in 2011). After being displayed at the [[Lewis and Clark Centennial Exposition]], it was donated to the American Museum of Natural History in New York City, where it has since been on display since 1906.<ref name="UofO">[http://natural-history.uoregon.edu/Pages/web/meteorite.htm Geology Tour.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051214235056/http://natural-history.uoregon.edu/Pages/web/meteorite.htm |date=2005-12-14}} University of Oregon: Museum of Natural History. Retrieved on October 31, 2007.</ref>
The meteorite was venerated by the [[Clackamas people]] inhabiting the area where it was found. The CTGRC, a confederation of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] tribes, used the meteorite, which they call ''Tomanowos'', in ceremonies and demanded that it be returned and filed an action pursuant to the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act (NAGPRA) against the American Museum of Natural History in 1999. In response, the Museum filed a federal lawsuit seeking a declaratory judgment against the CTGRC in 2000. An agreement with the Museum was reached later that year in which the meteorite would remain at the museum with tribal members being able to conduct a private ceremony around the meteorite once a year, and that ownership will be transferred to CTGRC should the museum cease to have the meteorite on display.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Sullivan |first=John |url=http://partners.nytimes.com/library/national/science/062300sci-meteor-pact.html |title=Pact Leaves Meteorite With Museum |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 23, 2000}}</ref>
In response to a student's request in 2007, [[Oregon House of Representatives|Representative]] [[John Lim]] introduced a resolution that would demand that the museum return the meteorite to Oregon. The tribes said they were not consulted, they did not support the resolution, and were content with the current arrangement with the museum.<ref>{{cite news | last=Walsh | first=Edward | title=Oregon's Pet Rock | url=http://blog.oregonlive.com/politics/2007/03/oregons_pet_rock.html | date=March 26, 2007 | access-date=2010-10-23}}</ref>
The {{convert|28|lb|kg|adj=on}} crown section of the meteorite that had been traded to the Macovich Collection for a [[Martian]] meteorite in 1997, was planned to be auctioned in October 2007, which led to claims by the CTGRC of insensitivity.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/02/14/national/14METE.html |title=Uproar Over a Sliced, and Revered, Meteorite |date=February 14, 2002 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/TECH/space/09/14/meteorite.auction.ap/index.html |title=Tribe: Sale of space rock 'insensitive' |work=CNN |date=2007-09-14 |access-date=September 15, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070914232152/http://www.cnn.com/2007/TECH/space/09/14/meteorite.auction.ap/index.html |archivedate=September 14, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/TECH/space/10/29/meteorite.auction.ap/index.html |title=Cow-killing meteorite sells for $1,554 |work=CNN |date=2007-10-29 |access-date=October 31, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071030171758/http://www.cnn.com/2007/TECH/space/10/29/meteorite.auction.ap/index.html |archivedate=October 30, 2007}}</ref> Bidders dropped out when an editorial in the Portland ''[[The Oregonian|Oregonian]]'' newspaper asserted the CTGRC would file a lawsuit against the new owner, but the CTGRC disavowed the editorial and said they had no such intent, and that they couldn't stop the sale. While the newspaper printed an apology, the specimen was withdrawn.<ref>Saturday, October 20, 2007 / Portland Oregonian — Apology/Retraction on the Editorial Page</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/09/14/native-american-tribe-alarmed-by-auction-of-a-meteorite-fragment/ |first=Sewell |last=Chan |date=September 14, 2007 |title=Tribe Alarmed by Auction of a Meteorite Fragment |work=The New York Times |access-date=November 28, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Tims|first=Dana|title=For sale: 30 pounds of controversy|url=http://blog.oregonlive.com/clackamascounty/2007/10/for_sale_30_pounds_of_controve.html|access-date=April 18, 2014|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|date=Oct 22, 2007}}</ref> A lawsuit was filed against the newspaper in Oregon Circuit Court and failed.<ref>Darryl Pitt v. Advance Publications, et al., Oregon Circuit Court, 0810-14798 (2008)</ref>
A {{convert|4.5|oz|g|adj=on}}, {{convert|7.5|in|cm|adj=on}} piece of the meteorite, also with a Macovich Collection provenance, was purchased in a 2006 auction and is on display at the [[Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum]] in [[McMinnville, Oregon]].<ref name=sn>{{cite web|url=http://www.salem-news.com/articles/april142006/meteorite_41406.php|title=Willamette Meteorite to Return to Oregon as Part of Evergreen Aviation Museum's Collection|publisher=Salem-News.com|access-date=2008-06-06|date=2006-04-14}}</ref><ref name=tims>{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/news/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/news/1212717408193720.xml&coll=7|last=Tims|first=Dana|title=Space history stands tall in museum| date=2008-06-06|access-date=2008-06-06|work=[[The Oregonian]]}}</ref>
==Mass== [[Image:Willamette Meteorite Marker.jpg|right|thumb|A historical marker in the Willamette area of [[West Linn, Oregon]]. The plaque reads: "In 1902 Ellis Hughes discovered the {{frac|15|1|2}} ton Willamette Meteorite, the largest ever found in the United States, about 2 miles N.W. of this place. Marker erected August 4, 1962 by West Linn Fair Board."]] There is some confusion about the actual mass of the Willamette meteorite due difference between [[tonne|metric tons]] and [[short ton]]s, often both called simply ''tons''. The result is that several sources report different weights, ranging from {{convert|15500|kg}}<ref name=database2>{{metbull|24269|Willamette}}</ref> to {{convert|12700|kg}}.<ref>Harry Y. McSween. [https://books.google.it/books?id=hFJ25RVuXfsC&pg=PA9&dq=Willamette+meteorite+kg&lr=&sig=ACfU3U0T6oUurVoo9-EfJ0ffiMJiSaiOFw#PPA9,M1 ''Meteorites and Their Parent Planets''.] Cambridge University Press, 1999.</ref> The official American Museum of Natural History Web site also reports both "''15.5 tons''"<ref>[http://www.amnh.org/rose/meteorite.html Planets Zone, Rose Center for Earth and Space.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221082443/http://www.amnh.org/rose/meteorite.html |date=2007-12-21}} American Museum of Natural History. Retrieved on August 16, 2008.</ref> and "''14 tons''".<ref>[http://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/permanent/meteorites/what/looklike.php Arthur Ross Hall of Meteorites.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705141615/http://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/permanent/meteorites/what/looklike.php |date=2008-07-05}} American Museum of Natural History. Retrieved on August 16, 2008.</ref><ref>[http://library.amnh.org/special/astronomy.html AMNH Special Collections: Astronomy slides.] American Museum of Natural History. Retrieved on August 16, 2008.</ref> However ''15,500 kg'' is likely 15.5 ''short tons'' converted as ''metric tons'' and ''12,700 kg'' is likely ''14 metric tons'' converted as ''short tons''. Moreover, in 1906 the American Museum of Natural History stated that the weight of the Willamette meteorite was ''at least 31,200 pounds, or about 15.6 tons''.<ref name=AMJ>The American Museum Journal, American Museum of Natural History, 1906.</ref> After these considerations it is reasonable to guess that the real weight of the meteorite is about {{convert|14150|kg}}.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}}{{Original research inline|date=August 2008}}
==Replicas== A [[Brown and Black Asteroid|replica of the meteorite]] is in [[Eugene, Oregon]], outside the [[University of Oregon Museum of Natural and Cultural History]] on the [[University of Oregon]] campus.<ref name="UofO" /> Another replica stands near the Willamette Methodist Church in West Linn, Oregon.<ref>[http://www.usgennet.org/alhnorus/ahorclak/WMSource.html The Willamette Meteorite, Information Sources and Links.] Clackamas County Oregon History and Genealogy. Retrieved on August 16, 2008.</ref> The only exact replica in existence is CNC-milled from a 3d model produced through photogrammetry by artist Garrick Imatani who worked in conjunction with the Confederated Tribes of Grand Ronde and the replica is currently installed in the Chachalu Museum at the Confederated Tribes of Grand Ronde in Grand Ronde, OR. The same artist has an interpretation of this meteorite on permanent display at the University of Oregon in Straub Hall. <ref> [http://klcc.org/post/sacred-meteor-be-celebrated-blessed-through-new-art-installation]
