{{Update|date=February 2018}} {{Women in warfare}} {{Women in society sidebar}} [[Image:F-15 pilots Elmendorf.jpg|thumb|250px|Four American [[McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle|F-15 Eagle]] pilots from the [[3d Wing]] walk to their jets at [[Joint Base Elmendorf-Richardson]].]]
[[Women]] have served in the [[military]] in various roles and in various jurisdictions throughout history.
Since 1914, in western militaries, women have served in greater numbers and more diverse roles than before. In the 1970s, most [[Women in the military by country|Western armies]] began allowing women to serve in active duty in all military branches.<ref>{{cite book |author=Carreiras, Helena |title=Gender and the military: women in the armed forces of western democracies |publisher=Routledge |location=New York |year=2006 |page=1 |isbn=978-0-415-38358-5 |url=https://www.google.com/books?id=h_teNrU9k6QC&pg=PA1}}</ref> In nine countries women are [[conscription|conscripted]] into military service.<ref>{{cite web|title=Women in the military — international|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news2/background/military-international/|website=www.cbc.ca|accessdate=17 Nov 2017|date=30 May 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Norway becomes first NATO country to draft women into military|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-norway-women-conscription-idUSBRE95D0NB20130614|agency=Reuters Staff|newspaper=Reuters|accessdate=17 Nov 2017|date=14 June 2013}}</ref> Only a few countries allow women to serve on an equal basis. They include Australia, Canada, Germany, Norway, Sweden and Denmark.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wiisglobal.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Women-in-Combat-Adaptation-and-Change-in-the-US-Military.pdf|title=Women in Combat: Adaptation and Change in the US Military|last=Haring|first=Ellen|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
{{TOC limit|2=3}}
==History== ===World War I=== {{Main|Women in World War I}}During the [[World War I|First World War]], the United States was in total warfare efforts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sq4ya5rf2q.search.serialssolutions.com/?genre=article&isbn=&issn=00028762&title=American%20Historical%20Review&volume=123&issue=4&date=20181001&atitle=Lynn%20Dumenil.%20The%20Second%20Line%20of%20Defense:%20American%20Women%20and%20World%20War%20I;%20Elizabeth%20Cobbs.%20The%20Hello%20Girls:%20America's%20First%20Women%20Soldiers.&aulast=Hendrickson,%20Mark&spage=1332&sid=EBSCO:America:%20History%20&%20Life&pages=1332-1334|title=Journals at the LMU William H. Hannon Library|website=sq4ya5rf2q.search.serialssolutions.com|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> Every person had to help in contributing to the war. However, this doesn't necessarily mean that everyone needed to fight. The country needed to continue to fund their troops and support the war financially while soldiers were fighting. The United States relied on organizations to support the war efforts. Women joined organizations such as the [[Committee on Public Information]] in order to educate people about the war. This committee additionally promoted nationality. In addition to working for committees having to do with education, women worked in all sorts of positions. Many women became [[YWCA USA|YWCA]] members and bravely went overseas to help soldiers. This was the first time in history that women of all classes were working together to help the war efforts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://americanhistory.si.edu/collections/object-groups/women-in-wwi|title=Women in World War I|website=National Museum of American History|language=en|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> Upper class women founded many voluntary war organizations while middle and lower class women worked in these organizations by working as nurses or by filling in the jobs of men.
Although all women were working to help their country, many women of color faced prejudice during this time.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oxfordaasc.com/article/opr/t0005/e1286|title=Oxford AASC: Home|website=www.oxfordaasc.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> Due to the war effort, many African American families moved from rural farms to urban cities. African American women were given the most hard working jobs with the lowest pay. Many organizations were formed, such as the Colored YWCA, to support African American women. These organizations helped these women find safe homes and stable jobs. They also hired many social workers to make it certain that employers treated women of color equally. Towards the end of World War I, black women were legally allowed to travel overseas to help the [[Red Cross]]. Many women from the Association of Colored Graduate Nurses were the first African Americans to help the Red Cross. Although this is a step in the right direction, the United States still has a long way to reduce prejudice and provide equal rights for African American women and people of color as a whole.
===Russia=== The only nation to deploy female combat troops in substantial numbers was [[Russia]]. From the onset, female recruits either joined the military in disguise or were tacitly accepted by their units. The most prominent were a contingent of front-line [[light cavalry]] in a [[Cossacks|Cossack]] regiment commanded by a female colonel, [[Alexandra Kudasheva]]. Others included [[Maria Bochkareva]], who was decorated three times and promoted to senior NCO rank, while ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that a group of twelve schoolgirls from Moscow had enlisted together disguised as young men.<ref>Susan R. Sowers, Women Combatants in World War I: A Russian Case Study" (Strategy Research Project, U.S. Army War College, 2003) [http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA414547 PDF]</ref> In 1917, the [[Russian Provisional Government|Provisional Government]] raised a number of "[[Women's Battalion]]s", with Bochkareva given an officer's commission in command. They fought well, but failed to provide the propaganda value expected of them and were disbanded before the end of the year. In the later [[Russian Civil War]], they fought both for the [[Bolsheviks]] (infantry) and the [[White movement|White Guard]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Reese|first=Roger R.|title=The Soviet military experience: a history of the Soviet Army, 1917–1991|publisher=[[Routledge]]|year=2000|page=17}}</ref>
===Others=== In [[Serbia]], a few individual women played key military roles. Scottish doctor [[Elsie Inglis|Elsie Ingles]] coordinated a retreat of approximately 8,000 Serbian troops through Romania and revolutionary Russia, up to Scandinavia and finally onto transport ships back to England .<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=SAVED 8,000 SERBS, BUT DIED IN EFFORT: Heroic Work Of Dr. Elsie Ingles Told by Woman Just Here from the Front.|last=|first=|date=February 11, 1918|work=New York Times|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=SERBIAN ARMY LED BY WOMAN: DRAMATIC RETREAT THROUGH RUSSIA|last=|first=|date=April 30, 1918|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=}}</ref> Another woman, [[Milunka Savić|Milunka Savic]], enlisted in the Serbian army in place of her brother. She fought throughout the war, becoming possibly the most decorated woman in military history.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.serbia.com/about-serbia/serbia-history/world-war-one/milunka-savic/|title=Milunka Savić the most awarded female combatant in the history of warfare|last=|first=|date=|website=www.serbia.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=ОШИЋ МАЛЕШЕВИЋ|first=Никола|date=2016|title=Review of: Милунка Савић – витез Карађорђеве звезде и Легије части|url=|journal=Tokovi Istorije|volume=1|pages=223–267|via=CEEOL}}</ref>
In 1917 [[Loretta Walsh]] became the first woman to enlist as a woman. A 1948 law made women a permanent part of the military services. In 1976, the first group of women were admitted into a U.S. military academy.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://norfolkdailynews.com/interactive/onlineextras/women-in-the-military/article_a21c355a-d822-11e2-87e3-001a4bcf6878.html|title=Women in the military|date=8 June 2013|newspaper=Norfolk Daily News|accessdate=2013-10-24}}</ref> Approximately 16% of the 2013 [[United States Military Academy|West Point]] class consisted of women.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/10/22/239260015/west-point-women-a-natural-pattern-or-a-camouflage-ceiling|title=West Point Women: A Natural Pattern Or A Camouflage Ceiling?|last1=Abramson|first1=Larry|date=22 October 2013|website=NPR.org|language=en|accessdate=17 November 2017}}</ref>In the 1918 [[Finnish Civil War]], more than 2,000 women fought in the [[Women's Red Guards of the Finnish Civil War|Women's Red Guards]].<ref>{{cite book|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2xCJBAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&hl=fi&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Finnish Civil War 1918: History, Memory, Legacy|last=Lintunen|first=Tiina|date=2014|publisher=Brill Publishers|isbn=978-900-42436-6-8|location=Leiden|pages=201–229|chapter=Women at War}}</ref>
In the [[Spanish Civil War]], thousands of women fought in mixed-gender combat and rearguard units, or as part of militias.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lines|first=Lisa|authorlink=Lisa Lines|date=May 2009|title=Female combatants in the Spanish civil war: Milicianas on the front lines and in the rearguard|url=https://www.capstoneediting.com.au/uploads/files/Female%20Combatants%20in%20the%20Spanish%20Civil%20War.pdf|journal=Journal of International Women's Studies|volume=10|issue=4|pages=168–187|accessdate=20 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Milicianas: Women in Combat in the Spanish Civil War (1936–1939)|last=Lines|first=Lisa|publisher=Lexington Press|year=2011|isbn=978-0-7391-6492-1|location=Plymouth, UK|authorlink=Lisa Lines}}</ref>
In 1990 and 1991, some 40,000 American military women were deployed during the [[Gulf War]] operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm; however, no women served in combat. A policy enacted in 1994 prohibited women from assignment to ground combat units below the brigade level.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/01/24/panetta-opens-combat-roles-to-women/|title=Military leaders lift ban on women in combat roles|last=Fischel|first=Justin|date=24 January 2013|newspaper=Fox|accessdate=24 October 2013}}</ref>
===World War II=== {{see also|Women in the World Wars}} [[File:Hrh_Princess_Elizabeth_in_the_Auxiliary_Territorial_Service,_April_1945_TR2832.jpg|thumb|left| Then-Princess Elizabeth served in the British Army, during the 1940s.]]
[[File:Roza Shanina.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Roza Shanina]], a Soviet sniper during [[World War II]], credited with 54 confirmed target hits. About 400,000 Soviet women served in front-line duty units,<ref name="D'Ann Campbell">{{cite journal |last=Campbell |first=D'Ann |title=Women in Combat: The World War Two Experience in the United States, Great Britain, Germany, and the Soviet Union |journal=[[Journal of Military History]] |year=1993 |volume=57 |issue= 2|pages=301–323 |url=http://americanhistoryprojects.com/downloads/ww2/women-combat.htm |doi=10.2307/2944060|jstor=2944060 }}</ref> chiefly as medics and nurses.]]
All the major participating nations in [[World War II]] enlisted women. The majority served as nursing and clerical or support roles. Over 500,000 women had combat roles in anti-aircraft units in Britain and Germany, as well as front-line units in the Soviet Union.
====United Kingdom==== In 1938, the [[British Empire|British]] took the lead in establishing uniformed services for women (small units of nurses had long been in service). In late 1941, Britain began conscripting women, sending most into factories and some into the military, especially the [[Auxiliary Territorial Service]] (ATS) attached to the army. The ATS began as a women's auxiliary in 1938. In 1941, the ATS was granted military status, although women received only [[Gender pay gap|two thirds of male pay]]. Women had a well-publicized role in handling anti-aircraft guns against German planes and [[V-1 flying bomb|V-1 missiles]]. The daughter of Prime Minister [[Winston Churchill]] was there, and he gushed that any general who saved him 40,000 fighting men had gained the equivalent of a victory. By August 1941, women were operating fire-control instruments; although they were never allowed to pull the trigger, since killing the enemy was considered to be too masculine.<ref>{{cite journal |first=G. J. |last=DeGroot |title=Whose Finger on the Trigger? Mixed Anti-Aircraft Batteries and the Female Combat Taboo |journal=War in History |year=1997 |volume=4 |issue=4 |pages=434–453 |doi=10.1177/096834459700400404 }}</ref> By 1943, 56,000 women were in [[Anti-Aircraft Command]], mostly in units close to London where they faced a risk of death, but not of capture.<ref name="D'Ann Campbell" /><ref>Schwarzkopf, 2009</ref> The first death of a woman in Anti-Aircraft Command occurred in April 1942.<ref>{{cite book|author=Sir Frederick Arthur Pile (bart.)|title=Ack-ack: Britain's defence against air attack during the Second World War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8BTTAAAAMAAJ|year=1949|publisher=Harrap|page=193}}</ref>
====Germany==== The [[Nazi Germany|Third Reich]] had similar roles for women. The [[Schutzstaffel|SS]]-Helferinnen were regarded as part of the SS if they had undergone training at a Reichsschule SS. All other female workers were contracted to the SS and chosen largely from [[internment|concentration camps]]. Women served in auxiliary units in the navy (Kriegshelferinnen), air force (Luftnachrichtenhelferinnen) and army (Nachrichtenhelferin).<ref name="Gordon Williamson 2003">Gordon Williamson, ''World War II German Women's Auxiliary Services'' (2003).</ref><ref name="Karen Hagemann 2011">{{cite journal | last1 = Hagemann | first1 = Karen | year = 2011 | title = Mobilizing Women for War: The History, Historiography, and Memory of German Women's War Service in the Two World Wars | url = | journal = Journal of Military History | volume = 75 | issue = 4| pages = 1055–1094 }}</ref> [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-B22251, DRK-Schwester mit EK II.jpg|thumb|180px|right|<nowiki>Second woman to win the Iron Cross, nurse Elfriede Wnuk</nowiki>]] In 1944-45 roughly 500,000 women were volunteer uniformed auxiliaries in the [[Bundeswehr|German armed forces]] (Bundeswehr). About the same number served in civil aerial defense, 400,000 volunteered as nurses and many more replaced drafted men in the wartime economy.<ref name="Karen Hagemann 2011"/> In the [[Luftwaffe]] they served in combat roles helping to operate anti-aircraft systems to shoot down Allied bombers. By 1945, German women held 85% of the billets as clerics, accountants, interpreters, laboratory workers and administrative workers, together with half of the clerical and junior administrative posts in high-level field headquarters.<ref>{{cite journal | first=D'Ann |last=Campbell | title=Women in Combat: The World War Two Experience in the United States, Great Britain, Germany, and the Soviet Union | journal = Journal of Military History | date=April 1993 | volume =57 |pages =301–323 | url = http://americanhistoryprojects.com/downloads/ww2/combat.htm | doi=10.2307/2944060 | issue=2|jstor=2944060 }}</ref>
The German nursing service consisted of four main organizations, one for [[Catholic Church|Catholics]], one for [[Protestantism|Protestants]], the secular DRK (Red Cross) and the "Brown Nurses," for committed [[Nazism|Nazi]] women. Military nursing was primarily handled by the DRK, which came under partial Nazi control. Frontline medical services were provided by male medics and doctors. Red Cross nurses served widely within the military medical services, staffing the hospitals close to the front lines and at risk of attack. Two dozen were awarded the [[Iron Cross]] for heroism under fire.<ref name="Gordon Williamson 2003"/> Brown Nurses were forced to look away while their incapacitated patients were murdered by [[War crime|war criminals]].<ref>Bronwyn Rebekah McFarland-Icke, ''Nurses in Nazi Germany'' (1999)</ref>
Hundreds of women auxiliaries (Aufseherin) served in the SS in the camps, the majority of which were at [[Ravensbrück]].
In Germany women worked and were told by Hitler to produce more pure [[Aryan race|Aryan]] children to fight in future wars.<ref>Leila J. Rupp, ''Mobilizing Women For War: German and American Propaganda, 1939-1945'' (1979)</ref>
'''Japanese American Women'''
During the second world war, many Japanese American women lost their jobs or pay because they were sent to [[Internment|relocation camps]]. Japanese immigrants and Japanese Americans were faced with discrimination. Many Americans called it the “yellow peril”<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Smith|first=Susan Lynn|date=1999-12-01|title=Women Health Workers and the Color Line in the Japanese American "Relocation Centers" of World War II|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/4392|journal=Bulletin of the History of Medicine|language=en|volume=73|issue=4|pages=585–601|doi=10.1353/bhm.1999.0190|pmid=10615767|issn=1086-3176}}</ref> and called Japanese people “japs”. In 1913, California passed the [[California Alien Land Law of 1913|Alien Land Law]] which prohibited “aliens ineligible for citizenship” from owning land to grow crops on. Despite the discrimination, many Japanese American women volunteered to serve in the [[Women's Army Auxiliary Corps|Women’s Auxiliary Army Corps]]. Sexism along with racism was something that these women faced when they joined WAAC. Even while dealing with discrimination, Japanese American women were able to greatly help the United States. Many women were hired as interpreters, translators, and interrogators in the [[Military Intelligence Service (United States)|Military Intelligence Service]]. In 1948, the Women’s Army Corps was permanently established and remained until 1978 when women were allowed into the army.
====Yugoslav Partisans==== {{main|Women in the Yugoslav Partisans}} The [[Yugoslav Partisans|Yugoslav National Liberation Movement]] had 6,000,000 civilian supporters; its two million women formed the [[Women's Antifascist Front of Yugoslavia|Antifascist Front of Women]] (AFŽ), in which the revolutionary coexisted with the traditional. The AFŽ managed schools, hospitals and local governments. About 100,000 women served with 600,000 men in [[Josip Broz Tito|Tito's]] [[Yugoslav Partisans|Yugoslav National Liberation Army]]. It stressed its dedication to women's rights and gender equality and used the imagery of folklore heroines to attract and legitimize the fighters.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Jancar | first1 = Barbara | year = 1981 | title = Women in the Yugoslav National Liberation Movement: An Overview | url = | journal = Studies in Comparative Communism | volume = 14 | issue = 2| pages = 143–164 }}</ref> After the war, although women were relegated to traditional gender roles, Yugoslavia's historians emphasized women's roles in the resistance. After Yugoslavia broke up in the 1990s, women's contributions to the resistance were forgotten.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Drapac | first1 = Vesna | year = 2009 | title = Resistance and the Politics of Daily Life in Hitler's Europe: The Case of Yugoslavia in a Comparative Perspective | url = | journal = Aspasia | volume = 3 | issue = | pages = 55–78 | doi=10.3167/asp.2009.030104}}</ref><ref>Barbara Jancar-Webster, ''Women and Revolution in Yugoslavia 1941–1945'' (1990)</ref>
===Vietnam War=== Though relatively little official data exists about female [[Vietnam War]] veterans, the Vietnam Women’s Memorial Foundation estimates that approximately 11,000 military women were stationed in Vietnam during the conflict. Nearly all of them were volunteers, and 90 percent served as military nurses, though women also worked as physicians, air traffic controllers, intelligence officers, clerks and other positions in the U.S. Women’s Army Corps, U.S. Navy, Air Force and Marines and the Army Medical Specialist Corps. In addition to women in the armed forces, an unknown number of civilian women served in Vietnam on behalf of the Red Cross, United Service Organizations (USO), Catholic Relief Services and other humanitarian organizations, or as foreign correspondents for various news organizations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2017/09/11/vietnam-war-timeline-u-s-involvement-over-decades/653693001/|title=Vietnam War: A timeline of U.S. entanglement|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-11-15|language=en}}</ref>
In addition to the U.S. military women who served in Vietnam, an unknown number of female civilians willingly gave their services on Vietnamese soil during the conflict. Many of them worked on behalf of the [[American Red Cross]], Army Special Services, United Service Organizations (USO), [[Peace Corps]], and various religious groups such as Catholic Relief Services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2013/07/01/world/vietnam-war-fast-facts/index.html|title=Vietnam War Fast Facts|last=Library|first=CNN|work=CNN|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref>
Other American women traveled to Vietnam as foreign correspondents for news organizations, including Georgette “Dickey” Chappelle, a writer for the National Observer who was killed by a mine while on patrol with U.S. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://linus.lmu.edu/search~S2?/yvietnam+war/yvietnam+war/-3%2C0%2C0%2CB/eresource&FF=ywomen+and+social+movements+in+the+united+states+1600+2000&1%2C1%2C/indexsort=-|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>Marines outside Chu Lai in November 1965. According to the Vietnam Women’s Memorial Foundation, 59 female civilians died during the conflict.
===Democratic Republic of the Congo=== [[File:Congolese female para-commando 1967.jpg|thumb|200px|A Congolese female para-commando during jump training at capital Leopoldville in 1967]] The [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] began training an initial 150 women as para-commandos for the [[Armée Nationale Congolaise]] in 1967. Many more were trained subsequently, over a period of years. The women received parachute and weapons training, although it is unclear to what extent they were actually integrated into the combat units of the Congo.
===Eritrea=== In 1999, the [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] reported that about a quarter of the [[Eritrea]]n soldiers in the [[Eritrean–Ethiopian War]] were women.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eritrea's women fighters|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/special_report/1999/07/99/battle_in_the_horn/396183.stm|website=news.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 November 2017}}</ref>
====Israel==== {{Main|Women in the Israel Defense Forces}} [[Israel]] is the only country with conscription for women.<ref name="serviceStatsAugust2010">{{cite web|title=Statistics: Women's Service in the IDF for 2010, 25 Aug 2010|url=http://idfspokesperson.com/2010/08/25/statistics-womens-service-in-the-idf-for-2010-25-aug-2010/|publisher=Israel Defense Forces|accessdate=22 March 2011|date=25 August 2010}}</ref><ref name="feldinger">{{cite news | author= Lauren Gelfond Feldinger | title = Skirting history | publisher= The Jerusalem Post | accessdate=22 March 2011 | date = 21 September 2008 | url = http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=114834 }}</ref><ref name="mfaWomen">{{cite web|title=Integration of women in the IDF|publisher=Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs|url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Israel+beyond+politics/Integration_women_in_IDF-March_2009 | accessdate=23 March 2011|date=8 March 2009}}</ref> Mandatory conscription for single and married women without children began in 1948.<ref name="idfBeg">{{cite web | url=http://www.idf.il/1283-9679-en/Dover.aspx | title=The Beginning, Women in the Early IDF | publisher=[[IDF Spokesperson]] | date=7 March 2011 | accessdate=14 August 2011}}</ref>
Initially, women conscripts served in the Women's Army Corps, serving as clerks, drivers, welfare workers, nurses, radio operators, flight controllers, ordnance personnel and instructors.<ref name="lcweb2.loc.gov">{{cite web|url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field%28DOCID+il0168%29 |title=Israel |publisher=Lcweb2.loc.gov |accessdate=16 November 2013}}</ref> Roles for women beyond technical and secretarial support began opening up in the late 1970s and early 1980s.<ref name="feldinger" />
In 2000, the Equality amendment to the Military Service law granted equal opportunities in the military to women found physically and personally suitable for a job. Women started to enter combat support and light combat roles in a few areas, including the Artillery Corps, infantry units and armored divisions. A few platoons named [[Caracal Battalion|Carakal]] were formed for men and women to serve together in light infantry. Many women joined the [[Israeli Border Police|Border Police]].<ref name="feldinger" />
Despite these changes, fewer than 4 percent of women service members are in combat positions such as infantry, crew of tanks or other armored vehicles, artillery guns service, fighter pilots, etc. Rather, they are concentrated in "combat-support".<ref name="Gaza: It's a Man's War">[https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2014/08/gaza-a-mans-war-israel-gender/375689/ Gaza: It's a Man's War] The Atlantic, 7 Aug 2014</ref>
===2017=== {{Main|Women in the military by country}}
The proportion of female military personnel varies internationally; for example, it is approximately 3% in India, 10% in the UK,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/uk-armed-forces-biannual-diversity-statistics-2017|title=UK armed forces biannual diversity statistics: 2017|last=|first=|date=2017|website=www.gov.uk|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref> 15% in France,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.senat.fr/rap/r14-373/r14-3731.pdf|title=Rapport d'information du Sénat N°373 : Des femmes engagées au service de la défense de notre pays|last=|first=|date=March 26, 2015|website=www.senat.fr|language=French|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> 13% in Sweden,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forsvarsmakten.se/sv/om-myndigheten/vara-varderingar/jamstalldhet-och-jamlikhet/historik/|title=Historik|last=Försvarsmakten|website=Försvarsmakten|language=sv-SE|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref> 16% in the US,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usarec.army.mil/support/faqs.htm|title=Support Army Recruiting|last=US Army|date=2013|website=www.usarec.army.mil|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref>, 15.3% in Canada<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/news/article.page?doc=women-in-the-canadian-armed-forces/izkjqzeu|title=National Defence {{!}} Canadian Armed Forces {{!}} Backgrounder {{!}} Women in the Canadian Armed Forces|last=Defence|first=Government of Canada, National|website=www.forces.gc.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-08-16|date=2018-03-07}}</ref>, and 27% in South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defenceweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=16708:fact-file-sandf-regular-force-levels-by-race-a-gender-april-30-2011-&catid=79:fact-files&Itemid=159|title=Fact file: SANDF regular force levels by race & gender: April 30, 2011 {{!}} defenceWeb|last=Engelbrecht|first=Leon|website=www.defenceweb.co.za|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref> While a marginal percentage of women are reported in military service globally, estimates following the increasing trend of military women capped predictions at about 10% for 1980.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Goldman|first=Nancy|date=1973|title=The Utilization of Women in the Military|journal=The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science|volume=406|pages=107–116|jstor=1039667}}</ref> As expressed by the current percentages, these numbers have not risen much passed that, with the exception of South Africa. Many state armed forces that recruit women continue to bar them from ground close [[combat]] roles (roles that would require them to kill at [[Close quarters combat|close quarters]]).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2013/01/25/map-which-countries-allow-women-in-front-line-combat-roles/|title=Map: Which countries allow women in front-line combat roles?|last=Fisher|first=Max|date=2013-01-25|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> This practice preserves male domination within militaries. In limiting female entry, militaries have maintained their characteristic brutal masculinity.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt183p28m|title=How a Century of War Changed the Lives of Women|last=GERMAN|first=LINDSEY|date=2013|publisher=Pluto Press|isbn=9780745332505}}</ref> Compared with male personnel and female civilians, female personnel face substantially higher risks of [[Sexual harassment in the military|sexual harassment]] and [[Military sexual trauma (United States armed forces)|sexual violence]], according to British<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/446224/ADR005000-Sexual_Harassment_Report.pdf|title=British Army: Sexual Harassment Report|last=UK, Ministry of Defence|date=2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-11}}</ref>, Canadian<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/85-603-x/85-603-x2016001-eng.htm|title=Sexual Misconduct in the Canadian Armed Forces, 2016|last=Canada, Statcan [official statistics agency]|date=2016|website=www.statcan.gc.ca|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-11}}</ref> and US<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Marshall|first=A|last2=Panuzio|first2=J|last3=Taft|first3=C|year=2005|title=Intimate partner violence among military veterans and active duty servicemen|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0272735805000619|journal=Clinical Psychology Review|language=en|volume=25|issue=7|pages=862–876|doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2005.05.009|pmid=16006025|via=}}</ref> research. Not only have women been left unprotected, but the major cause of PTSD experienced by women is identified as military sexual trauma (MST). The male experience of PTSD derives from that of combat trauma.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt183p28m|title=How a Century of War Changed the Lives of Women|last=GERMAN|first=LINDSEY|date=2013|publisher=Pluto Press|isbn=9780745332505}}</ref>
==Combat== {{main|Women in combat}} {{globalize/US|section|date=November 2013}} [[File:Marie Marvingt in Deperdussin aeroplane 1912.jpg|thumb|right|[[Marie Marvingt]] was the first female pilot to fly during a wartime; she was never in combat (1912)]] Some nations allow female soldiers to serve in certain combat arms positions. Others exclude them for various reasons including physical demands and privacy policies. Among the NATO nations, and as of the mid-1970s, women were able to attain military status in the following countries: Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Greece, the Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and the United States. Non-conscription countries, notably the United States, the United Kingdom, and Canada are where the highest levels of female military presences were achieved.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Stanley|first=Sandra Carson|last2=Segal|first2=Mady Wechsler|date=July 1988|title=Military Women in NATO: An Update|url=|journal=Armed Forces & Society|language=en|volume=14|issue=4|pages=559–585|doi=10.1177/0095327x8801400405|issn=0095-327X|via=}}</ref> Canada is marked as particularly progressive in its early implementation of gender equality practices.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt183p28m|title=How a Century of War Changed the Lives of Women|last=GERMAN|first=LINDSEY|date=2013|publisher=Pluto Press|isbn=9780745332505}}</ref> A rise in the call for equal opportunity coupled with the decline of able-bodied men willing to enter military service coaxed countries to reform policies toward female inclusion.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Stanley|first=Sandra Carson|last2=Segal|first2=Mady Wechsler|date=July 1988|title=Military Women in NATO: An Update|url=|journal=Armed Forces & Society|language=en|volume=14|issue=4|pages=559–585|doi=10.1177/0095327x8801400405|issn=0095-327X|via=}}</ref> . With the opening of submarine service in 2000, women now had free reign to enlist in any kind of military service.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt183p28m|title=How a Century of War Changed the Lives of Women|last=GERMAN|first=LINDSEY|date=2013|publisher=Pluto Press|isbn=9780745332505}}</ref> Despite their gender-neutral approach, a lack of female retention programs have kept female military participation to about 15.3%.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt183p28m|title=How a Century of War Changed the Lives of Women|last=GERMAN|first=LINDSEY|date=2013|publisher=Pluto Press|isbn=9780745332505}}</ref>
===United States=== The [[United States military]] opens all positions to women.<ref>{{cite web|title=Army Jobs For Women: Different Positions For Women In The Military - Militaro|url=http://militaro.com/army-jobs-for-women|website=militaro.com|accessdate=7 November 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150329005503/http://militaro.com/army-jobs-for-women|archivedate=29 March 2015}}</ref> Units such as [[United States Special Forces|Special Forces]] require members to meet extraordinary requirements, and no females have met them in some units.
====History==== Women have been involved in the U.S. military since 1775, originally in the civilian fields of nursing, laundering, mending clothing and cooking.
[[Deborah Sampson]] was one of the first women to enlist while disguised as a man. She was unhappy with her limited role in the [[American Revolution]]. She served in a light infantry unit, fighting in many battles. Injuries put her in a hospital where her secret was discovered. Her commanding officer, General John Paterson, honorably discharged her and thanked her for her service.<ref name="graduate.norwich.edu">{{Cite web|url=https://graduate.norwich.edu/resources-mmh/articles-mmh/how-roles-have-changed-for-women-in-the-military/|title=How Roles Have Changed for Women in the Military {{!}} Norwich Online Graduate Degrees|website=graduate.norwich.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-20}}</ref>
Several hundred women enlisted and fought in the [[US Civil War]], generally disguised as men. In some cases their identity was discovered, typically on the battlefield or in hospitals after becoming wounded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.civilwar.org/education/history/untold-stories/female-soldiers-in-the-civil.html|title=Female soldiers in the Civil War on the front line|last=Smith|first=Sam|website=www.civilwar.org|accessdate=17 November 2017|date=2013-01-25}}</ref>
In 1917 [[Loretta Walsh]] became the first woman to enlist as a woman. A 1948 law made women a permanent part of the military services. In 1976, the first group of women were admitted into a U.S. military academy.<ref>{{cite news|title=Women in the military|url=http://norfolkdailynews.com/interactive/onlineextras/women-in-the-military/article_a21c355a-d822-11e2-87e3-001a4bcf6878.html|accessdate=2013-10-24|newspaper=Norfolk Daily News|date=8 June 2013}}</ref> Approximately 16% of the 2013 [[United States Military Academy|West Point]] class consisted of women.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Abramson|first1=Larry|title=West Point Women: A Natural Pattern Or A Camouflage Ceiling?|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/10/22/239260015/west-point-women-a-natural-pattern-or-a-camouflage-ceiling|website=NPR.org|accessdate=17 November 2017|language=en|date=22 October 2013}}</ref>
In 1990 and 1991, some 40,000 American military women were deployed during the [[Gulf War]] operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm; however, no women served in combat. A policy enacted in 1994 prohibited women from assignment to ground combat units below the brigade level.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fischel|first=Justin|title=Military leaders lift ban on women in combat roles|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/01/24/panetta-opens-combat-roles-to-women/|accessdate=24 October 2013|newspaper=Fox|date=24 January 2013}}</ref>
====Policy changes==== Until 1993, 67 percent of the positions in the Army were open to women.
In 2013, 15.6 percent of the [[United States Army|Army's]] 1.1 million soldiers, including [[Army National Guard|National Guard]] And [[United States Army Reserve|Reserve]], were female, serving in 95 percent of occupations.<ref name="army">{{cite web|url=http://www.army.mil/article/110447/Sisters_in_Arms__Breaking_down_barriers_and_rising_to_the_challenge/|title=Sisters in Arms: Breaking down barriers and rising to the challenge|accessdate=24 October 2013}}</ref> As of 2017 78 percent of the positions{{Clarify|reason=positions vs occupations? Otherwise data don't make sense.|date=September 2018}} in the Army are open to women.<ref>{{cite web|title=Women in the U.S. Army|url=http://www.army.mil/women/today.html|website=www.army.mil|accessdate=17 November 2017}}</ref> In the [[U.S. Air Force]], 99% of career fields are open to women, with the only exceptions [[United States Air Force Special Tactics Officer|Special Tactics Officer]], [[Combat Control]], [[Special Operations Weather Technician]], [[Combat Rescue Officer]], [[Pararescue]] and [[United States Air Force Tactical Air Control Party|Tactical Air Control Party]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=McGowan|first1=Bailey|title=Air Force testing gender-neutral standards in San Antonio|url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/story/military/2015/05/23/air-force-testing-gender-neutral-standards-in-san-antonio/27848207/|website=Air Force Times|accessdate=17 November 2017|date=7 August 2017}}</ref>
In January 2013, the US ended the policy of "no women in units that are tasked with direct combat".<ref name="armywomen">{{cite web|url=http://www.army.mil/article/118930/Army_to_open_33_000_positions_to_female_Soldiers_in_April/|title=Army to open 33,000 positions to female Soldiers in April|author=C. Todd Lopez|publisher=Army News Service|date=27 January 2014|accessdate=30 January 2013}}</ref>
In 2013 female U.S Army soldiers enrolled in a training course designed by [[Combined Joint Task Force Paladin]], specifically designed for Female Engagement Team members. The course was intended to train female soldiers for tasks such as [[unexploded ordnance]] awareness, [[biometrics]], [[Forensic science|forensics]], evidence collection, tactical questioning, vehicle and personnel searches and homemade explosive devices.<ref>{{cite web|last=Drohan|first=Ed|title=CJTF Paladin offers training for female engagement team members|url=http://www.army.mil/article/111974/CJTF_Paladin_offers_training_for_Female_Engagement_Team_members/|accessdate=24 October 2013}}</ref>
By May 2015, none of the nineteen women vying to become the first female [[United States Army Rangers|Army Rangers]] had passed [[Ranger School]]. Eleven of the nineteen dropped out in the first four days. Of the remaining eight who failed in the next step, three were given the option to.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Michaels|first1=Jim|title=Women in Ranger School fail to finish grueling course|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/05/30/ranger-women/28179303/|accessdate=31 May 2015|work=[[USA Today]]|date=30 May 2015}}</ref> Two graduated in August 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jordan|first1=Mary|last2=Lamothe|first2=Dan|title=How did these two women become the first to complete Army Ranger School?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/how-did-these-two-women-become-the-first-to-complete-army-rangers-school/2015/08/19/a745c962-46af-11e5-8ab4-c73967a143d3_story.html|accessdate=19 October 2015|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=19 August 2015}}</ref> A third graduated in October 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lamothe|first1=Dan|title=Army Ranger School has a groundbreaking new graduate: Lisa Jaster, 37, engineer and mother|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/10/12/army-ranger-school-has-a-groundbreaking-new-graduate-lisa-jaster-37-engineer-and-mother/|accessdate=19 August 2015|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=12 October 2015}}</ref>
In April 2015 after two-and-a-half year period in which the [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]]' Infantry Officer Course became gender-integrated for research ended without a single female graduate.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/04/08/last-ioc-marine-experiment-women/25478813/ |title=Marines' combat test period ends without female grad |accessdate=6 January 2016 |website=www.usatoday.com}}</ref> The final two participants failed the initial Combat Endurance Test.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/story/military/2015/04/07/last-ioc-in-marine-experiment-drops-two-officers/25418867/ |title=Last IOC in Marine infantry experiment drops female officers |website=www.marinecorpstimes.com |accessdate=6 January 2016 }}</ref>
In 2016 all combat jobs opened to women.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Baldor|first1=Lolita C.|title=Officials: Marine commandant recommends women be banned from some combat jobs|url=http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/story/military/2015/09/18/officials-marine-commandant-recommends-women-banned-some-combat-job/72421888/|website=Marine Corps Times|accessdate=17 November 2017|date=7 August 2017}}</ref>
Women have been injured, killed, and awarded high honors. Two women received the [[Silver Star]]: Sgt. Leigh Ann Hester in 2005 and Army Specialist Monica Lin Brown in 2007 for their actions in combat. Over 10,000 combat action badges were awarded to women who served in combat in [[Iraq War|Iraq]] and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/opinion/op-ed/la-oe-1204-lemmon-women-combat-20151204-story.html|title=Women in combat? They've already been serving on the front lines, with heroism|last=Lemmon|first=Gayle Tzemach|website=latimes.com|access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/opinion/op-ed/la-oe-1204-lemmon-women-combat-20151204-story.html|title=Women in combat? They've already been serving on the front lines, with heroism|last=Lemmon|first=Gayle Tzemach|date=|website=latimes.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref>
====Physical, social, and cultural issues==== [[File:Defense.gov News Photo 100806-M-0301S-111 - U.S. Marine Cpl. Mary E. Walls right an ammunition technician and linguist Sahar both with a female engagement team patrol with 1st Battalion.jpg|thumb|Two members of a US Marine Corps Female Engagement Team patrolling a town in Afghanistan during 2010]] [[File:Ryazan Airborne School 2013 (505-10).jpg|thumb|280px|Russian military's women contingent in their formal wear during a parade, 2013]]
A 2015 [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]] study<ref name="Washington Post">{{cite news|last1=Lamothe|first1=Dan|title=Marine experiment finds women get injured more frequently, shoot less accurately than men|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/09/10/marine-experiment-finds-women-get-injured-more-frequently-shoot-less-accurately-than-men/|accessdate=16 December 2015|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=10 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Adamczyk|first1=Ed|title=U.S. Marines study: Women in combat injured more often than men|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2015/09/10/US-Marines-study-Women-in-combat-injured-more-often-than-men/6121441908304/|accessdate=8 September 2016|work=[[UPI]]|date=10 September 2015}}</ref> found that women in a unit created to assess female combat performance were significantly injured twice as often as men, less accurate with [[infantry]] weapons and not as good at removing wounded troops from the battlefield.<ref name="Washington Post"/>
The study assessed a nine-month experiment at [[Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune|Camp Lejeune]], N.C., and [[Twentynine Palms, California|Twentynine Palms]], Calif. About 400 [[Marines]], including 100 women, volunteered to participate.<ref name="washingtonpost.com">{{cite news|last1=Lamothe|first1=Dan|title=Marine experiment finds women get injured more frequently, shoot less accurately than men|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/09/10/marine-experiment-finds-women-get-injured-more-frequently-shoot-less-accurately-than-men/|accessdate=12 December 2015|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=10 September 2015}}</ref>
Male squads, teams and crews demonstrated better performance on 93 of 134 tasks evaluated (69 percent) than units with women in them. Male units were faster while completing tactical movements in [[combat]] situations, especially in units with large "crew-served" weapons such as heavy machine guns and mortars. Male [[infantry]] squads had better accuracy than squads with women in them, with "a notable difference between genders for every individual weapons system" used by infantry rifleman units. The [[M4 carbine]], [[M27 Infantry Automatic Rifle|M27]] infantry automatic rifle and [[M203]] single-shot [[grenade launcher]] were assessed.<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/>
Male [[Marines]] who had not received [[infantry]] training were more accurate than women who had. In removing wounded troops from the battlefield, "notable differences in execution times were found between all-male and gender-integrated groups".<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/>
[[Unit cohesion]] was lower in mixed gender units. Many female soldiers reported that the way that they are viewed by male soldiers is often detrimental to their participation. For instance, female soldiers are often labelled as "either standoffish or a slut".<ref name=doan2017>{{cite journal|last1=Doan|first1=Alesha E.|last2=Portillo|first2=Shannon|title=Not a Woman, but a Soldier: Exploring Identity Through Translocational Positionality|journal=Sex Roles|date=2017|volume= 76|issue=3–4|pages=236–249|doi=10.1007/s11199-016-0661-7|hdl=1808/23881}}</ref> In order to avoid such labels, female soldiers have to spend time with fellow soldiers strategically, without spending too much time with any one of them. This approach often has an isolating effect.<ref name=doan2017 /> In several instances, women were considered less skilled than male soldiers, so were not given opportunities to complete tasks for which they were qualified.<ref name=doan2017 />
According to Lt. Col. Dave Grossman, author of ''On Killing: The Psychological Cost of Learning to Kill in War and Society'', Israeli soldiers reacted with uncontrollable protectiveness and aggression after seeing a woman wounded. Further, Islamic militants rarely, if ever, surrender to female soldiers, lessening the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF']]<nowiki/>s ability to take prisoners. Iraqi and Afghan civilians are often not intimidated by female soldiers. However, in socially conservative environments, female combat soldiers can search female civilians, while children and women are more likely to talk to female soldiers than to male soldiers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://coalitionforveterans.org/2011/04/female-soldiers-say-theyre-up-for-battle/ |title=Coalition for Iraq & Afghanistan Veterans » Blog Archive » Female soldiers say they're up for battle |publisher=Coalitionforveterans.org |accessdate=16 November 2013}}</ref>
=====Sexual harassment and assault===== {{See also|Sexual harassment in the military|Sexual assault in the United States military|Sexual assault in the Canadian Forces}} One 2009 report concluded that military women were three times more likely to be raped than civilians;<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8005198.stm|title=Americas | Women at war face sexual violence|date=17 April 2009|accessdate=16 November 2013|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> and that women soldiers in Iraq were more likely to be attacked by another soldier than by an insurgent.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/rep-jane-harman/finally-some-progress-in_b_125504.html|title=Rep. Jane Harman: Finally, Some Progress in Combating Rape and Assault in the Military|date=10 September 2008|accessdate=16 November 2013|publisher=Huffingtonpost.com}}</ref> In 1988, the first military-wide [[sexual harassment]] survey found that 64% of military women had been subjected to some form of sexual harassment. The most affected were [[Native Americans in the United States|Native-Americans]], followed by [[Hispanic|Hispanics]] and [[African Americans|African-Americans]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Women and Gender Volume Two|last=|first=|publisher=Academic Press|year=2001|isbn=978-0-12-227247-9|location=|pages=775–776}}</ref>
==== Sexual assault: What it is and the Process ==== Sexual assault is more likely to occur in the military than in the civilian population. One in four active-duty female military personnel will be sexually assaulted.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1177/0886260506295347|pmid = 17202575|title = Mental Health, Quality of Life, and Health Functioning in Women Veterans|journal = Journal of Interpersonal Violence|volume = 22|issue = 2|pages = 179–197|year = 2007|last1 = Surìs|first1 = Alina|last2 = Lind|first2 = Lisa|last3 = Kashner|first3 = T. Michael|last4 = Borman|first4 = Patricia D.}}</ref> The military has a Code Of Justice which defines sexual assault: rape, aggravated assault, abusive sexual assault, nonconsensual sodomy (forced oral or anal sex), or attempts to commit these acts.
All of these acts are punishable by military law which begins by the victim going forward to their commander. It is then their job to make an inquiry on the perpetrator, however they also have the right to dismiss the claims. They can also the right to take non-judicial punishment or take it to high authority. If the perpetrator's punishment can go from dismissal, to dishonorable discharge to confinement in military prison. If found with the crime of rape the perpetrator can carry a lifetime of imprisonment to in extreme cases even execution.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://military.findlaw.com/criminal-law/military-sexual-assault-the-basics.html|title=Military Sexual Assault: The Basics|work=Findlaw|access-date=2018-11-15|language=en-US}}</ref> When women went to report their sexual assault 83% of the victims stated that their experiences with military legal personnel made them reluctant to seek further help.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Castro|first=Carl Andrew|last2=Kintzle|first2=Sara|last3=Schuyler|first3=Ashley C.|last4=Lucas|first4=Carrie L.|last5=Warner|first5=Christopher H.|date=2015-05-16|title=Sexual Assault in the Military|journal=Current Psychiatry Reports|language=en|volume=17|issue=7|pages=54|doi=10.1007/s11920-015-0596-7|pmid=25980511|issn=1523-3812|citeseerx=10.1.1.640.2867}}</ref>
Many victims in the military describe the response to and aftermath of sexual assault as more painful than the assault itself because of the unspoken "code of silence." The code of silence implicates that women should keep quiet about their assault and not come forward to take action. Women expect that little will be done, so most cases go unreported. When they are reported and taken to court only ten percent of cases have the perpetrator charged for their crimes, which is a reason women won't come forward as they know little will come from it.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Castro|first=Carl Andrew|last2=Kintzle|first2=Sara|last3=Schuyler|first3=Ashley C.|last4=Lucas|first4=Carrie L.|last5=Warner|first5=Christopher H.|date=2015-05-16|title=Sexual Assault in the Military|journal=Current Psychiatry Reports|language=en|volume=17|issue=7|pages=54|doi=10.1007/s11920-015-0596-7|pmid=25980511|issn=1523-3812|citeseerx=10.1.1.640.2867}}</ref>
Female soldiers have developed several techniques for avoiding sexual assault "including: (1) relying on support networks [<nowiki/>[[buddy system]]s], (2) capitalizing on their status (associated with rank, age, time spent in military, or prior deployment experience); and, (3) masking femininity through clothing to minimize violence exposure and to keep themselves and others safe during military service".<ref name="cheney2015">{{cite journal|last1=Cheney|first1=Ann M.|last2=Reisinger|first2=Heather Schact|last3=Booth|first3=Brenda M.|last4=Mengeling|first4=Michelle A.|last5=Torner|first5=James C.|last6=Sadler|first6=Anne G.|title=Servicewomen's Strategies to Staying Safe During Military Service|journal=Gender Issues|date=March 2015|volume= 32|issue= 1|pages=1–18|doi=10.1007/s12147-014-9128-8}}</ref> Such strategies leave the burden of addressing the problem on potential victims.<ref name="cheney2015" /> Conversely, in many units, soldiers pair off as "buddies" who watch out for each other. In mostly male units, females buddy with males who then often becomes excessively protective, reducing the female's [[Agency (philosophy)|agency]].<ref name="weitz2015">{{cite journal|last1=Weitz|first1=Rose|date=September 2015|title=Vulnerable Warriors: Military Women, Military Culture, and Fear of Rape|journal=Gender Issues|volume=32|issue=3|pages=164–183|doi=10.1007/s12147-015-9137-2}}</ref>
A lawsuit seeks redress for military plaintiffs who claim to have been subjected to sexual assault.<ref>{{cite news|author=Lucy Broadbent |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2011/dec/09/rape-us-military |title=Rape in the US military: America's dirty little secret | Society |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=16 November 2013 |location=London |date=9 December 2011}}</ref> ''[[The Invisible War]]'' addresses this lawsuit and topic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://invisiblewarmovie.com/page.cfm?id=12 |title=The Invisible War: Home |publisher=Invisiblewarmovie.com |accessdate=16 November 2013}}</ref>
==== Effects of sexual Assault ==== Sexual assault leads to many health problems for women in the military such as anxiety disorders, such as post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), depression, substance abuse, binge eating, dissociation and memory impairment, suicidal and parasuicidal behavior, sexual dysfunction and dissatisfaction, poor self-esteem, and personality disorders, such as borderline personality disorder.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://watermark.silverchair.com/milmed-d-10-00038.pdf?token=AQECAHi208BE49Ooan9kkhW_Ercy7Dm3ZL_9Cf3qfKAc485ysgAAAkIwggI-BgkqhkiG9w0BBwagggIvMIICKwIBADCCAiQGCSqGSIb3DQEHATAeBglghkgBZQMEAS4wEQQMjlJ5fV1_Vgl5BwzzAgEQgIIB9RT5h5Zzgszxdu45nuyLb9quGE9LS6S5lXdoJQYaNA5avXHnG8xQJ_o-ube5T6coQoPQbWTaDR5biO4t9ifKoqfgA13LgM2zKy1mo8KSC_2OgvgyhXy2ZQVngkT04dHG3H98sqEnA6Qk-Aili7qRKJM_nWIcPBw7cBtFmEvebi78s2ZHJbLZ0DGVUpvBvcDnNJ-7qaeH2VEjKDeNgSS-Eaovo0JnjcXr72USJpcym-nz5in--vzrHH09x6dAWk2qdID0W4yh7GKIGmjyZAHjA34vveE7PzfkcUlXLXFoVu5M5QcjfheteaQwhmX1102VO1_YsdH6bRt1LqFLBfKaUkxA4-YLBai2frbT6v9LDn1EnKNgrpOxwsf4PFJXUCiaBK19WhzfE50IBuoqQopn1VbjYaHNNFqaiAaHbS3YXkZVzXZCtlcVGBdgBm1gqtRI4DRTZSqD8pU4NLwM5y6p4mRQkU8yyq1hkW1rspXdmwnIEzigVoaLps63IiN3UX8XsF1WzOpDotOqhcl1LZ8jjllNdlFQS-EkU72QONZZsWyBCL-8b0QS5c7GzObIxDQfQYpuvM6sxtIpGr40pmaJa8lhtTFKp4t-plDBL6OE1UcmZD3KRfRIAMuJ_CfI9AiVf4zG9CeAAHnhgzjcS1djVEUig79ihAWomen|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> It also takes a toll on their physical health and have reported having menstrual complications, headaches, back pain, gastrointestinal pain.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=SAGE Journals: Your gateway to world-class journal research|journal=Journal of Interpersonal Violence|volume=22|issue=2|pages=179–197|url=https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/0886260506295347.|language=en|doi=10.1177/0886260506295347|pmid=17202575|year=2007|last1=Surìs|first1=Alina|last2=Lind|first2=Lisa|last3=Kashner|first3=T. Michael|last4=Borman|first4=Patricia D.}}</ref>
All of these factors make it hard for women to stay in the military, in women it is the leading cause for early leave of the armed forces. Once leaving the military though women have a hard time reintegrating back into society and can end up homeless. It is so debilitating for women in the military because most of their perpetrates are people they work and live with, from peers to a supervisor and higher above. This close relationship creates a new type of trauma as the victim is forced to see them every day and creates an overall lack of trust in people<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Sexual Assault in the Military|journal=Current Psychiatry Reports|volume=17|issue=7|pages=54|doi=10.1007/s11920-015-0596-7|pmid=25980511|year = 2015|last1 = Castro|first1 = Carl Andrew|last2=Kintzle|first2=Sara|last3=Schuyler|first3=Ashley C.|last4=Lucas|first4=Carrie L.|last5=Warner|first5=Christopher H.|citeseerx=10.1.1.640.2867}}</ref>.
They more often fail to complete college, and generally earn incomes less than $25,000.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sadler|first1=Anne|last2=Booth|first2=Brenda M.|last3=Nielson|first3=Deanna|last4=Dobbeling|first4=Bradley N.|title=Health Related Consequences of Physical and Sexual Violence|journal=Obstetrics and Gynecology|date=2000|volume=96|issue=3|pages=473–480|doi=10.1016/s0029-7844(00)00919-4|citeseerx=10.1.1.454.2108}}</ref> Their work can involve frequent interactions with their attacker, and damages trust in the institution. Perpetrators are typically in a higher position have the job to protect the woman, increasing trauma.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kip|first1=KE|last2=Hernandez|first2=DF|last3=Shuman|first3=A|last4=Witt|first4=A|last5=Diamond|first5=DM|last6=Davis|first6=S|last7=Kip|first7=R|last8=Abbayakumar|first8=A|last9=Wittenburg|first9=T|last10=Girling|first10=SA|last11=Witt|first11=S|last12=Rosenzweig|first12=L|title=Comparison Of Accelerated Resolution Therapy (ART) For Treatment Of Symptoms Of PTSD And Sexual Trauma Between Civilian And Military Adults|journal=Military Medicine|date=2015|volume=180|issue=9|pages=964–971|doi=10.7205/milmed-d-14-00307|pmid=26327548}}</ref>
Updated military training focuses on bystander interventions and the role of [[consent]] in sexual activity, emphasizing the responsibility of male soldiers.<ref name="weitz2015" /> Some female soldiers assume the classically male role of "protector". This works to change women's "responsibility for preventing rape"<ref name="weitz2015" /> and requires that male soldiers acknowledge their responsibility to engage with female soldiers in all activities.
===Women on submarines=== [[File:Female Australian submariner on board HMAS Waller in 2013.jpg|thumb|A female Royal Australian Navy submariner aboard [[HMAS Waller (SSG 75)|HMAS ''Waller'']] in 2013]][[File:Flickr - Official U.S. Navy Imagery - Women submariners meet President Obama..jpg|thumb|U.S. Navy's women submariners meet [[President Obama]], 2012]]
In 1985 the [[Royal Norwegian Navy]] became the first<ref name="WLatUSM">{{cite web|url=http://www.isn.ethz.ch/isn/Current-Affairs/Security-Watch/Detail/?lng=en&ots627=fce62fe0-528d-4884-9cdf-283c282cf0b2&id=123253|title=Women, Leadership and the US Military: A Tale of Two Eras|date=11 Aug 2010|accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref> navy in the world to permit female personnel to serve in submarines. The first female submarine commander was Captain [[Solveig Krey]] aboard the first [[Kobben-class submarine|Kobben class submarine]] on 11 September, 1995. <ref>{{cite web|title=U-34 submarine, Eckernforde, 02.05.07 ; Freeze Frame - The Independent (London, England) {{!}} HighBeam Research|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-5882245.html|website=The Independent|url-access=subscription |accessdate=17 November 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515203116/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-5882245.html|archivedate=15 May 2013|date=3 May 2007}}</ref> The [[Danish Navy]] allowed women on submarines in 1988, the [[Swedish Navy]] in 1989,<ref name="WLatUSM"/> followed by the [[Royal Australian Navy]] in 1998, Canada in 2000 and Spain.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/military-international/ |title=Women in the military - international |date=30 May 2006 |work=Indepth |publisher=CBS News |accessdate=21 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111014025906/http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/military-international/ |archivedate=14 October 2011 }}</ref>
On April 29, 2010, the United States Navy authorized women to serve aboard submarines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=52990|title=Navy Welcomes Women To Serve In Submarines|author=Commander, Submarine Group 10 Public Affairs|publisher=Navy.mil|accessdate=16 November 2013}}</ref> Previously, objections such as the need for separate accommodation and facilities (estimates that modifying submarines to accommodate women would cost $300,000 per bunk versus $4,000 per bunk on aircraft carriers) had prevented the change.<ref>[http://armedforcescareers.com/articles/article18.html ''New Debate on Submarine Duty for Women''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927064245/http://armedforcescareers.com/articles/article18.html|date=2007-09-27}} Armed Forces Careers retrieved 11 August 2007</ref> The Navy stated that larger [[Cruise missile submarine|SSGN]] and [[Ballistic missile submarine|SSBN]] submarines had more available space and could accommodate female officers with little/no modification. Qualified female candidates with the desire to serve were available. (Women then represented 15 percent of [[active duty]] sailors<ref name="Information, 2009">Navy Office of Information, "Women on Submarines", Rhumblines, 5 October 2009.</ref> and were earning about half of all science and engineering bachelor's degrees.)<ref name="Information, 2009" /><ref>{{cite web|author=Commander, Submarine Forces Public Affairs |url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=52954 |title=Navy Policy Will Allow Women To Serve Aboard Submarines |publisher=Navy.mil |accessdate=16 November 2013}}</ref>
In May 2014, it was announced that three women had become the UK [[Royal Navy]]'s first female submariners.<ref>{{cite news|title=Royal Navy gets first female submariners|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-27278588|accessdate=5 May 2014|newspaper=[[BBC]]|date=5 May 2014}}</ref>
On November 15, 2017, the first Argentinian female submarine officer [[:es:Eliana_Krawczyk|Eliana Krawczyk]], disappeared in the Atlantic Ocean after the Argentinean Navy lost contact with ''ARA San Juan'' submarine after a reported failure in the electric system.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/argentina-jews-honor-female-submarine-officer-lost-at-sea/|title=Argentina Jews honor female submarine officer lost at sea|access-date=2018-08-16|language=en-US}}</ref> As one of the 44 crew members lost at sea, Krawczyk was honoured by the country's Jewish community as "La Reina De Los Mares" on International Women's Day in 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://misionesonline.net/2018/03/08/dia-la-mujer-recordaron-sentido-homenaje-eliana-krawczyk-la-submarinista-desaparecida-ara-san-juan/|title=Día de la Mujer: recordaron con un sentido homenaje a Eliana Krawczyk, la submarinista desaparecida en el ARA San Juan - MisionesOnline|date=2018-03-08|work=MisionesOnline|access-date=2018-08-16|language=es-ES}}</ref>
On July 4, 2017, after two years of training, four female officers boarded a French SSBN for France's first seventy-day mixed gender patrol.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.defense.gouv.fr/marine/actu-marine/premiere-patrouille-de-snle-avec-quatre-femmes-a-bord |website=Ministère des Armées |title=Première patrouille de SNLE avec quatre femmes à bord |accessdate=2018-08-16}}</ref> The next generation of French submarines are designed to welcome women.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Groizeleau |first1=Vincent |title=Les Premières Femmes de la Sous-marinade Française |url=http://www.meretmarine.com/fr/content/les-premieres-femmes-de-la-sous-marinade-francaise |accessdate=2018-08-16 |agency=Mer et Marine |date=2018-07-19}}</ref>
Women are expected to join submarine crews in the [[Royal Netherlands Navy]] in 2019, with the addition of shower doors and changing room curtains.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.volkskrant.nl/nieuws-achtergrond/vrouwen-gaan-voor-het-eerst-mee-in-onderzeeer-dus-komen-er-gordijnen-en-douchedeurtjes-voor-de-privacy~ba7e404c/ |title=Vrouwen gaan voor het eerst mee in onderzeeër, dus komen er gordijnen en douchedeurtjes voor de privacy |date=9 Oct 2018 |lang=nl}}</ref>
==Academic studies== [[File:Military parade on Red Square 2017-05-09 028.jpg|thumb|Russian female cadets.]] A 2008 study found that female cadets saw military training as an "opportunity to be strong, assertive and skillful" and saw such training "as an escape from some of the negative aspects of traditional femininity". The female cadets also believed that the ROTC program was "gender-blind" and "gender-neutral". The study claims that female cadets "were hyper-vigilant about their status as women performing tasks traditionally seen as men's work and often felt that they had to constantly prove they were capable."<ref name=":0" />
The study quoted one female cadet: "in the Navy the joke is that a woman in the Navy is either a bitch, a slut or a lesbian, and ''none of them are good categories to fall into'', and if you are stern with your people then you are a bitch, but if you're a guy and stern people are like, wow, I respect him for being a good leader."<ref name=":0" />
84 percent of cadets said they did not want a military career as it would interfere with marriage and raising children.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal | author = Jennifer M. Silva | year = 2008 | title = A New Generation of Women? How Female ROTC Cadets Negotiate the Tension between Masculine Military Culture and Traditional Femininity | journal = Social Forces | volume = 87 | issue = 2 | pages = 937–960 | jstor=20430897 | doi=10.1353/sof.0.0138}}</ref>
A 2009 study examined the attitudes of West Point cadets, [[Reserve Officer Training Corps]] (ROTC) cadets, and non-military-affiliated students from civilian colleges toward a variety of military roles. Cadets were less approving of assigning women to certain military jobs than others.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Matthews|first=M.D |author2=Ender, Morten G. |author3=Laurence, J.H. |author4=Rohall, D.E. |title=Role of group affiliation and gender attitudes toward women in the military|journal=Military Psychology|year=2009|volume=21|issue=2|pages=241–251|doi=10.1080/08995600902768750}}</ref>
